content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
http://cnc-online.net/ <- go here for multiplayer.With that out of the way, let me just remind you of what you're getting into here - everything about this game is over-the-top - the story, the characters, the artstyle, the units, the actresses' cleavage. Basically, a Red Alert game like any other, maybe except for that last part.There are three factions to choose from, the Allies, the Soviet Union, and the Empire of the Rising Sun. Don't ask. Okay, you just had to, fine. Einstein invented the time machine, erased Hitler from the timeline. Soviets got ballsy and started WWII instead of Nazi Germany which is now nonexistent. Then Allies kicked their asses twice, and at that point they invented a time machine of their own to kill Einstein. "Wait, that would mean there is Nazi Germany now and-" No, shut up and go defend your refinery from cryocopters.Behind the nonsense of a story, there is a jewel of RTS design, hands down. Every unit has a secondary attack, meaning more micro options. There are air, land and sea units (every building except barracks and war factory can be built on water), some can freely switch between two or even all three. Every faction is unique to play down to the way they build their bases, each has something different to offer depending on your preferences and they're overall balanced relative to each other. People might tell you that Allies are the best faction which is kind of true but there was a time when they said the same about Empire so whatever. Just play Soviets, they have bears.

												The Good:Red Alert 3 is a great game. The easy user interface combined with the fast action make me choose this game over Starcraft II on a nearly daily basis. The multiplayer is amazing, and the game is incredibly balanced. Unfortunately, the game does not have a massive online community. You end up running into the same people, time and time again.The Bad:As a fan of Red Alert 1 and 2, I found the campaign to be COMPLETELY destroyed by EA. Real actors, combined with cartoony stuff, and Tanya having blonde hair. It made me cringe. If you're looking to play the campaign, and not delve into the incredible tactics within the multiplayer... don't bother. This game is not for you.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Command and Conquer does it again with another great installment onto the Red Alert series. Although not as good as its predecessor C&C: RA3 continues to offer no need for builders and no worry of controlling population. Gameplay:Unlike past Red Alerts I only played about one skirmish as I did not find the AI as enjoyable as the predecessors. This Red Alert offers some interesting new teams and resource harvesting concepts which seem different than before. Like in the past Red Alert games the Russians and Allies are pretty much the same basic strategy type, while the third team offers a fresh new tactics. Similar to past Red Alerts to expand bases (when playing as either Allies or Soviets) you can build Mobile Construction Vehicles. But, unlike past Red alerts they have also added the ability for Prospectors (allied ore miners) to deploy into Command Centers which allow you to expand to nearby areas mitigating large costs. The USSR can build “Sputnik” which can also deploy into a command center. Both of these units allow for cheaper base expansion. This is different for the Japanese whose buildings are built by transforming vehicles into buildings and thus are not limited to base parameters. Campaign:The campaign took me about 21 hours to complete (that includes Allies, Russians, and Rising Sun missions). Interestingly the campaigns intertwine and in some instances you play the same missions but just as the opposing team, which I sort of liked. In the case of this game the missions are not exactly gripping, but that is the case with all strategy games. The campaign offers a great composition of actors which make you laugh, gasp, and reminisce in the old days when you first sat down and played Red Alert. Some of the missions are very quick and last no time at all while others can last a couple hours. Results:If you are expecting something just like the second Red Alert then you will be disappointed. There is only one Yuri and his revenge was an epic adventure that could only be told once. If you are interested in playing a strategy game that brings Red Alert on a new adventure then this is a game worth checking out. With an amazing intro song to boot and epic campaign cut scenes that you won't forget. Red Alert 3 really takes Westwood’s dream into action: hot babes who flirt with you throughout your entire game and keep your spirits bolstered with cheesy lines. Pros:+Great campaign with fun dialogue and amazing cut scenes.+New Empire of the Rising Sun team which brings all new tactics to the game+Campaign missions that don't just require you to continually build a base over and over again, but rather test you through a variety of scenarios.+Epic main menu music that just makes you want to jump right into the Russian campaign. +It has been 18 years and Tanya still hasn't aged over 30... a mystery? Or did someone use the chronosphere?Cons:-Its not Red Alert 2 (that game already existed, if you want that game you may want to go find the disk from your shelf)-Some campaign missions can run rather long, while others last about 10 minutes. (Some missions took me up to three hours). -Poor movement AI can cause units to not exactly act how you want them too.

content:
Posted: January 20
												7 out of 10 Red Alert 3 is a decent, yet confused real time strategy game.  Good:  1. I love that you have proper movies in between missions, even though the acting is over the top.  It fits fantastically with the less than realistic game.  The game is worth playing just for the videos. 2. Interesting units. Land, air and sea.3. Good balance between factions. Bad: 4. Every unit has one, and only one, special ability. It works better if some units have no special abilities and others are spell casters with lots of abilities. 5. The game is confused.  Red Alert and Red Alert 2 were amazing old style slow strategy games.  Those games were all about careful resource management - not unit management. RA3 tries to find a middle ground to a faster pace and more focus on unit management.  As result it falls in between, succeeding at neither style. Ugly:6. the psychic Japanese girl never features in any video. O how I which Steam would give as Red Alert and Red Alert 2.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
TL:DR? See ConclusionNOTE: I have played this game extensively, but not on Steam.INTRODUCTION:Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game serving as the third installment of the popular Command & Conquer series.  It features a rebooted story and a brand new faction called 'The Empire of the Rising Sun'.  However, unlike its predecessors,  Electronic Arts who acquired Westwood Studios, the original developers of the game, produced Red Alert 3.  It is one of the last few remaining franchises who use live action cutscenes which the series is known for.Players once again take the role of the unknown commander who leads either the Allied Forces, the Soviet Army, or the newly resurrected Imperial Armed Forces to ultimate victory.Red Alert 3's story starts with the Soviet Union in complete collapse after the events of Red Alert 2.  In an effort to stop the USSR's defeat, surviving Soviet leaders use a time machine to go back in history and erase Albert Einstein in order to prevent him from developing Allied technology.  Upon returning to the Present day however, they discover that without Einstein, nuclear technology was  never developed.  With this turn of events, this meant that the US never bombed Japan and the Empire never surrendered during World War 2.  Now the Empire has risen once more and poses a new threat to both the Soviets and the Allies prompting the hilarious line by actor Peter Stormare as Dr. Gregor Zelinsky: “We now have...two mortal enemies?” PROS:+ Colorful visuals and very nice graphics with good use of Physx technology+ New 'Empire of the Rising Sun' faction is fun to play featuring highly advanced, extremely versatile, very expensive, and unhealthily suicidal units (ex. Tsunami Tank: “HA! Give us a good death”  Imperial Warrior:  “Death before defeat!” Shogun Battleship:  “Ramming speed!” Yari Sub:  “We're taking you with us!” + Fun campaign for all 3 factions+ Hilarious, Hammy, Cheesy but overall good voice acting+ Humorous and entertaining Tutorial+ All units for all factions now have secondary abilities+ Co-op campaign+ Very nice Music and SoundsCONS:- The very colorful art-style that could cause headaches for some people- Some low polygon models, low resolution shadows, and poor textures can be seen here and there- Short campaign for each faction- Story is shallow and uses way to many cliche elements from the previous Red Alert 2- Occasional pathfinding problems- Balance issues with some of the units- Some outstanding bugs that was never fixed (for some reason, changing the graphics quality and  resolution at the same time MAY cause a crash)- Despite EA's vast resources and use of big name actors like Peter Stormare and George Takei, I can't help but feel that they were not able to live up to the standard of Westwood.- Broken multiplayer on Steam (No idea if it works in Origin)CONCLUSION:GREAT RTS GAME.  Although it does not fully capture the magic of Red Alert 2, Red Alert 3 still delivers a great fast paced experience for RTS fans looking for a quick fix.  The campaign is fun with a story that is easy to follow but uses a lot of cliche plot elements.  The Soundtrack is excellent and the over-the-top, hammy, and cheesy voice acting are very entertaining.  Multiplayer is also fun if you're looking for a casual RTS experience since the AI does pose a challenge on higher difficulties.  In addition, new game mechanics such as the secondary abilities and the new faction spices up the action.Now we come on whether or not I recommend this game.  If you're in this for the single player experience, sure I can RECOMMEND this game easily.  If you're in this for the multiplayer experience, I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game here on Steam because for some reason the Servers are broken so you're better off purchasing this in EA's Origin Platform.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												Red Alert 3 is a game that signals the end of a series. Not because it's a bad game, it's a fairly mediocre one, but because everything that defined Red Alert and made it different from the rest has gotten completely away from the designers.The graphics has gone full on cartoon which might work for some people but for me it just makes me cringe. The science is silly as always but the units, particularly the animal units will make your sense of logic die a little. The national stereotypes are just bordering on full blown racism and the cleavage is in your face and everywhere.The biggest feature of this game is the ability to play through all the campaigns in coop-mode and while is this a great feature it is also one that dies pretty fast. You can't just buy it and boot it up and expect there to be coop partners available.All in all, it's not a terrible game, it's just not a very good one either. All the things that made Red Alert a special game has been completely ruined.

number of helpful: 32 of 40 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is a real-time strategy game and obviously the follow-up to Red Alert 2. While I absolutely loved Red Alert 2 I can't say the same for this title.First, there are some things Red Alert 3 does well. The storyline is as cheesy as it comes and that is what fans expect and love. It is also great that the game has actors like Tim Curry, George Takei and David Hasselhoff, who really seem to enjoy performing the B-movie-like storyline.However, Red Alert 3 has many problems compared to its predecessor. The units have a cartoonish look to them and look like child's toys. Many of them look so over the top that it is just ridiculous. Also, the weapon's effects and sounds don't convey any impact, further reinforcing that impression.The gameplay itself comes off as very hectic because units cannot take any damage, no matter the unit type. Even the biggest tanks and ships give off the impression of being made of paper. They get destroyed within seconds leaving no room for actual micromanagement. The problem is that the game wants the player to micromanage since every unit has some sort of special ability. There is not much room to use them however and I would have preferred not having them at all except the toggled abilites. The units' AI is also pretty bad. If the enemy has a slightly longer range they will refrain from retaliating and just get destroyed. Anti-air weaponry is extremely underwhelming in this game. Often building turrets don't seem to make no sense at all. Even if you have a solid turret setup there is just not much use in defending since there are so many units that can destroy your base from huge distances. If the enemy uses aircraft they will still destroy your base because there is no defense that will keep them from destroying at least one target in every run.Red Alert 3 features a computer controlled partner in every campaign mission. This partner can be replaced by a human player and while I appreciate the idea of making the whole campaign able to be played coop it just doesn't work. The computer partner is highly unreliable in its performance. In some missions it will basically win the mission by itself with you struggling to keep up with the pace and in some missions it will be literally useless. During the last mission of the Rising Sun campaign my AI partner was actually unable to even defend its own base. When I didn't continually sent units there my partner would just be annihilated within a few minutes. All of this while I had my own problems, being hammered by airstrikes, superweapons and ground troops.The campaign should come with a trigger warning (pun intended) because all missions are heavily built around triggers that you most of the time cannot see coming. However you need to be prepared for them because if you're not you have basically lost. There is no reaction time since the game is fast and units and buildings cannot withstand any damage. It's bad design if you can only win by being able to see into the future. If you have run your head into the wall a few times you will know the triggers and it basically becomes a minigame of avoiding those. One of the worst examples is from the Rising Sun campaign. At one point you will be confronted with a huge enemy fleet and have to hold out until your battleships arrive. When they arrive it is still not enough to destroy the enemie's base but you absolutely need to destroy all their shipyards. Why you ask? Because the AI will start producing an indefinite amount of aircraft carriers and since anti-air turrets are horribly weak you will lose.Red Alert 3 is not a horrible game but is has so many shortcomings compared to its predecessor that I cannot recommend it at all.P.S.: If you liked the Tanya from Red Alert 2 you will be severely disappointed.More reviews here

number of helpful: 40 of 61 people (66%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												This is, to my mind, the best Command & Conquer game out there. Some complain about the blatant fanservice with respect to the use of well-edowed female actrices in the hammy videos, while others believe that Red Alert 3 has gone too far with respect to the silliness inherent in the series (i.e. the use of war bears by the Soviets and the mecha-inspired units in the army of the Empire of the Rising Sun). To me, all that stuff is simply silly fluff that shouldn't be taken seriously. What should be taken seriously is the gameplay. The game is a refined version of the Command & Conquer style of real-time strategy game: a simple economy (you build powerplants to power your structures and harvest ore to get money to buy more buildings and units) with an emphasis on the spectacle of battle. Units are fragile, so expect many of them to be destroyed more or less as soon  as you encounter enemy forces. Hard counters are used, which means that some units, for example, have no defences against air units, or are weak against certain types of infantry, and so forth. This means that reconaissance is as important if not more so as in other RTS games. Red Alert 3 is more micro-heavy than most of the other games in the series. Each and every unit has a toggable special ability (hotkey F), and use of these special abilities will prove essential in most battles. Combined with the speed at which units move and their fragile nature, this means that games can get very hectic, very fast. It's for this reason that I mostly avoid multiplayer: I know that I won't be good enough to compete anyway. Instead, I stick to singleplayer and it's loads of fun. The game has three factions and each of them gets their own campaign, with each campaign consisting of nine missions each. The different factions are the Allies, the Soviets, and a new third faction especially developed for this game, namely the Empire of the Rising Sun (essentially Japan). The Allies emphasize their air power, while the Soviets field relatively sturdy ground troops and can spit out a lot of units. The Empire is a high-tech faction with specialized units (remember: F is your friend!) and probably the most difficult to play by newcomers. The leaders of each of these factions are played by well-known actors: Vincent Pryce, Tim Curry, and George Takei, respectively. I've put many hours into the disc version of the game before buying it anew on Steam and do not regret a single minute that I spent playing the game. The campaign is entertaining and can also be played fully in co-op mode. If you don't have any friends, an AI will take over. The AI sometimes really helps out during missions, but more often than not simply forms a distraction that the enemy AI will occupy itself with while you build your base and reinforce your army. If the campaign is not your cup of tea, you can always play skirmishes against the computer or go online (there is a replacement out there for GameSpy, so the online component does still work, thanks to the fans).

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Isn't as addictively fun as Red Alert 2 and Yuri's Revenge, but, you know what? It's still fun, and it's different enough from other CnC games (in a good way, unlike CnC 4) to stand out on it's own. Like, there's a pretty interesting balance between naval and ground combat that doesn't make either feel like an afterthought, and the campaigns, while campy with pointless fanservice and mindnumbing writing, offer diverse scenarios.Now, one thing I really hate, it has lots of unnecesseary micro. Not only is the game full of hard counters so you have to order around units so they wouldn't get owned by their counters while concentrating their fire onto weakest targets, pretty much every unit has it's own gimmick special, be it a special attack or alternative fire mode, so the amount of unnecesseary micro is unberable. Red Alert 2 kept it way more simple, and if unit had several firing modes you wouldn't need to switch between them, meanwhile here it's not even Starcraft or CoH levels of micro. Worst offender is the new third faction, Empire of the Rising Sun. They have probably the most of alternative modes due to sizeable chunk of their force being transformers like a machinegun mecha that switches into a fighter and such, and you can't switch back for some time like you get with, say, Starcraft 2 vikings, so it's rather annoying.Units in general are pretty cool, even if there are some familiar ones like Natasha Volkova not only sharing the cyborg's from Red Alert 1 name but also being pretty much Yuri's Revenge Boris crossed with GLA's Jarmen Kell. IFVs are exactly the same too, but they are light ATVs and not paper-thin armored vehicles now. Tesla Troopers, despite having an AoE paralysis alt-fire mode, are exactly the same slow knuckleheads as before. The more unique units are alsothe more bizarre ones, say soviets have APCs that instead of deploying troops fire them out of a circus cannon just to have them land with parachutes, Allies have helicopters equiped with freeze and shrink rays (the first just paralyse and weaken affected targets, meanwwhile shrink rays make units punny, squishy, squeaky-voiced but also fast), and Empire has anime schoolgirl psychics, katana infantry, obligatory mechas and even more obligatory ninjas!Now, visuals! Units are absolutely cartoony and bright, which is forgiveable considering general tone, but Soviet aesthetics are attrocious. They have some sweet designs like Sickle, but their heavy armor and structures are butt-ugly and look more silly than threatening. Some structures even have those Kremlin towers slapped on, like in RA2. Except it worked in RA2 because red brick buildings with towers did look like Kremlin, and RA3's towered soviet buildings look like turtles with erection! One thing that's actually gorgeous is the sea, which makes sense considering you get as much naval action as ground. Oh and soundtrack is great. They had Klepacki write only the Hell March but this other composer seems to be talented, too.Other stuff worth mentioning: there are no permament upgrades you research like in Generals or CnC3, instead you get experience points in battle that are then redeemed for special abilities and upgrades, which can be quite a game changer. Also there is co-op but to be honest considering the fact campaign isn't really difficult while playing on your own with a dim-witted AI companion, I wouldn't expect it to be a challenge for two players, plus most of the time it's just "Player 1 takes on ground forces, Player 2 takes on naval forces". Uprising standalone expansion has some actually challenging missions but ironically lacks in co-op functionality.Overall I could recommend this even for die-hard CnC fans, unless they're not fond of dense and campy setting or hate micro, and it's definitely a must-try for anyone interested in an enjoyable and accessible RTS.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												An underrated RTS gem that's just plain fun. I can understand why C&C fanboys might dislike it; it doesn't take itself seriously whatsoever. The Allies command Dolpins with sonar pulse weapons, the Soviets have zeppelin-like Kirov Airships, and the Empire has frickin' Warriors with beam katanas. The units, story and cutscenes are all over-the-top ridiculous but it's highly entertaining. The gameplay is as intense as ever, and the cell-shaded graphics are beautiful, especially the crisp blue water. The difficulty scaling is very good; even though I was once Masters in SC2 I went Easy mode for a nice, relaxing playthrough. Medium isn't too bad if you want to play missions a couple times. Overall this game is just excellent in every aspect.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I want to make a note, that I've only played RA3 for about 6 - 7 h when writing this "review".I can see a fun game in there somewhere, but one major thing really kills the gameplay for me; at least during th solo campaing, and that is the shared economy. I really hate that. Since the AI is always building stuff you can't save up money for things to build, and you are ALWAYS short of resources because of this. It is really frustrating! I was looking forward to having a full co-op campaign when I bought this game, but I was not ready for that design decision.Otherwise I've been surprised about how well this holds up as a sequel to RA2 and YR. And it is fun that we finally get a main campaign that focuses on the Sovjet side. Sure, previous games have always had the sovjet campaign aswell, but that was not the main story. And having such a great actor-rooster adds to the experience.The amoun of bewbs (or cleavage) this game shows can be discussed. The twelve-year old inside my 25 year old body is happy, but the game would have been just as good (perhaps better) without it.So how does the game feel then?Basically this game is a mixture of the previous C&C titles. You've got the familiar units, all though redesigned, from the RA-series with addition of new units. You've also got the micromanagment system from RA2, which was lacking in the Generals-series; waypoints and hold-fire and stuff like that. Then again, some controls and features from the Generals series have found its way in here. It is really odd to see units and gameplay first feeling like generals, but then also feeling like RA2. I'm not sure I'm all that fond of the mixture yet.I'm sure my view on this game will change as time goes by. And if I manage to get online I will add that experience to this review later on. Will I recommend this game for new players? Well if you have RA2/Yuri's Revenge and you somehow manage to play that online then stick with that game, because it is more fluent than this. At least in my humble opinion.If you don't have anything else, I can surley see this as a viable option. And for 5 dollars on steam it is worth it.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Awesome! Great addition to a great franchise. One of the games that pioneered high production value cutscenes and live action performances that elevate the experience to a new level.I found myself laughing at the enemy taunts (which of course were presented by seasoned actors and performers giving the game that often missing "social feel"). Classic RTS game play with three completely different play styles for each give it a high replay value. Add skirmishes and it will keep you playing long after the campaigns are done.Recommended for fans of the franchise or lovers of RTS and strategy genre. Great graphics, great performances all around and an engaging if not over the top plot with the feel of a big budget hollywood production. I only ever write a review if I feel strongly enough to do so and this is one of them for certain. Looking forward to future titles carrying or expanding upon the tradition that Westwood studios so boldly started when it had the Dune franchise. Command and Conquer rocks! I can't say enough about the use of live action performers and great voice talent as well. It just gives so much life to the whole experience.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												Everyone will tell you that this game is a continuation of the wacky shenanigans that happened in RA2, but I really don't remember the game being that wacky and silly. Case in point, in Yuri's Revenge, there was a building that ground up troops for resources all while using slave labor.Mind you, this was also a game where you fight dinosaurs and hollywood stars were actually commandoes, but I can also say that with the combination of frank klepacki's unapologetically metal soundtrack combined with equal amounts ridiculous and awesome units and set pieces, RA 2 worked on a level that couldn't be replicated.That being said, RA3 is in no way the game that anyone was looking for. See, what sets RA2 above other RTS games is the idea that a gamebreaker should be countered with a gamebreaker. Just remember the chronotroops and the psychich commandos, its a game with glorious power creep that encourages you to out-do your opponent.That being said, not only did EA make a pathetic attempt to balance this game, nothing feels as crazy or nearly as fun. Or as balanced.A focus on naval warfare means that Rising Sun in theory should have an advatage, but with no viable anti-air until at least 2nd tier dock/factory, and to be honest I never used it. Everything feels squishy and underpowered, and nothing is as interesting as it was in RA2, and although Klepacki's soundtrack is fun, its not nearly as engrossing as it was in his other works.If you're really jonesing for a CnC game, get tiberium wars/wrath of kane.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												So it's one of the few good EA titles on Steam, and it's not saddled with some other atrocious DRM. As for the game itself, it's a super colourful, campy fun time. The campaign is three factions long, each with their own ways of playing (the Empire of the Sun units probably require more micro), not to mention the fact that there's a naval component to factor in. Coupled with a good variety of traditional RTS mission styles, and you've got a really lengthy campaign for its genre, before even setting foot in MP (SP only review, no experience with matchmaking, connectivity, etc.)But let's be honest though, you play this game to see Tim Curry yuck it up as a Soviet Premier, among other standouts like J.K. Simmons, Jonathan Pryce, George Takei, the Nature Boy Ric Flair (Uprising expansion) and a requisite lineup of pinup females. It's an anachronistic, yet heartfelt throwback to C&C's heyday during the 90s FMV trend, which is super appropriate given the time-travelling shennanigans this B-movie cooks up for it's stupidly fun plot.

												I would not suggest this game to anyone who was a fan of the original Red Alert/2/Yuri's Revenge or even C&C Generals, EA and whatever is left of Westwood is long gone and dead.  This game does not have an enjoyable campaign, the units are basic and boring, and it is not fun thus defeating the purpose of it being classified as a "game".  The campaign is flat out dull and boring, the witty cutscenes that went hand in hand with good gameplay are no longer there, EA has seen fit to simply have bad acting encompass their bad game design just so they can say "look we remember what RA used to be too!"  The units are boring and made out of paper, the fun general powers from C&C Generals make a return but with None of the fun or innovation that the previous title put into it.  Factional units are cut and paste from each other with only some different looking models and alternate modes being the variation.  The units in general show the worst signs of AI that I have ever seen in ANY RTS title or game that I have played PERIOD.  They are extremely near-sighted; they always fail to return fire unless you give them a direct order and will just sit there getting blown away by everything.  Speaking of alternate unit modes, this game tries to do something different and fails utterly, the only thing that these abilities do is further complicate the most BASIC C&C formula and further hamper the gameplay and fun factor of the title.  Even when you have them built with attack at will rather then defensive they will consistently neglect to defend themselves even when the enemy unit is right on top of them, it is babysitting of the highest order and a huge failing of the “game” and its developers.  The “future” has shown that any C&C title past Generals or maybe the earlier 3D C&Cs have been a complete failure as fans continue to drop the titles in favor of something less driven by greed and fake innovation.During the campaign you can either have a coop human player, if you can keep connection with EA’s trash servers (another quality sign of EA) or you can be aided by the in game AI, which is semi competent enough however the kicker is that for an RTS game you and your coop player share ore resources, which is absolutely ridiculous and a really poorly thought-out mechanic.  On the subject of the campaign again I will clarify further that it is one of the most boring three faction story mode that I have ever played let alone failing to bring me any joy from playing it.  I have to push myself in order to go back to it and attempt to finish it that’s how I consider the story mode and the game in general, boring and a CHORE, no game should ever make the player feel that way!  I am very glad that I never got this game when it came out for the full price and even then $10 for a 2008 title I still feel ripped off and the price proves that EA will never stop being a money grubbing parasite. To add to this, Steam needs to change the description of this game since as of now the Gamespy servers have been shut down indefinitely so the online Coop and multiplayer are no longer a functioning entity of this title.The music of C&C has always been memorable this is especially the case with the Red Alert series.  However in RA3 they have yet again gone away from being GOOD and simply moved to the most repetitious garbage that I have had to listen to repeated through the ENTIRE CAMPAIGN.  You will hear a single song for the entirety of each an every single mission within the campaign as well as the multi and skirmish section, not ONCE is the famous Red Alert song played at any point within the game short of the menu, that is yet more proof that there is no longer a Command and Conquer series of RTS games at all.  They have simply screwed up on the entire game, which amazingly enough extends to even the music score which is unbelievable.  I am saddened that this title got such higher praises then I feel that it should have, as if the fans were so hopeful to the possibilities of the new EA Westwood titles that everyone seems to have given this game a pass regardless to how bad it truly is.  I feel sorry that the younger generations after me will never again know how good C&C titles used to be and that based on this, my last C&C title that I will buy, we will never see the good days again.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												C&C: RA3 is one of those very much so rare games that even though all competition from newer RTS-titles, still have managed to remain just as fun to play at the current as back when they were initially released. With this IP, EA Los Angeles introduced to us (the players) one of the very best of gaming-experiences ever crafted, let alone one which one could ever have asked for. EALA gave us players lots of additional features and tools both advanced as simple that made and still makes this game from the bigger rest.The Developers gave us the very best, with features such as the fantasticaly simplictic hosting-system of which still runs as smooth as ever and in which one didn't need to set up a entiere f*****g home-based server in-order to do so.The RA3 Worldbuilder map-editor which was and once again still remains one of the simplest and most time-saving/conserving map-editors ever to have been introduced to the gaming community.The Brutal smart-AI's,.. although admittedly not being the hardest nor smartest in all of gaming history, did give us quite a ride with their smart and uncountable use of tactics which they 'occasionally'' deployed with great cunning fighting alonside or versus the players.The SuperWeapons, even if 'yes a bit anoying'' did by fact bring us that underlying sense of fear of imminent destruction and the feeling that the favors might swing to your opponents side in any number of seconds. It made for a crucial part of the RA3 playing mentality.They gave us a truly unqiue set of factions whom opperated in very distinct ways from one another and of which employed different tactics for the various of tasks.Lastly, they gave us the Replay, one of the first in-whole trully so good theater-modes as far as RTS-IPs' are concerned.Now, too finish off this way too overly extensive review of mine I shall end by proclaiming in-accordance with personal opinion, that Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 most-probably am one of the very best game-IPs' to have been crafted in reccent memory. -:"Spoken In The Common Man's Langauge; It Would Be Fair To Considered It My Nr.1 Favorite Game Of All Time."(Rating: 11/11)

												Solid gameplay, good campaign, and intriguing units. This truely is the sequel to red alert 2 with its querkyness and all. Although this game does not take itself very seriously it is massively fun to play for hours on end. Strategy is key in this game where you have many options of assault and you are able to take research and development in different areas to see what is effective. You will soon learn after playing the strengths and weaknesses of each faction and just how to play as each. This game decides to mix naval air and ground battles just as in red alert 2 but it is done better as you have the worry of being snuck up on by enemy fleets, or bombed by bombers.This game is great and I enjoy it more than many of the other command and conquer games out there. Definitely buy this and if you enjoy the campaign or just single player battles but wish for more units then buy the expansion pack it is worth the money if you don't mind no multiplayer which really is a shame.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Sometimes the soul of a person, or a game, is laid bare in a single moment. In Red Alert 3, there is a Soviet general with six stars per shoulder, dozens and dozens of medals and a coffee mug decorated with Soviet iconography. In one mission briefing he gravely warns that "Our enemies are thrusting deeply into Mother Russia's tender nether regions." It only gets better when the Soviet Hammer Tank exclaims "It's hammer time!" and moves to engage. The best thing about all this is that the actual gameplay follows suit, being both fast-paced and relaxing. Graphical style is very gonzo and bright and fits the subject matter perfectly, as does the gloriously nonsensical soundtrack. Red Alert 3 is silly harmless fun that has not aged a bit in five years.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2012
												There are two things in particular that make this game: the humour, and the co-op. Truth be told, I haven't played through either of the previous Red Alert games, so I wouldn't know how this is as a sequel. However, on it's own, this game is very fun, especially if you play through it with a friend. Not a lot of RTS games offer co-op throughout their campaign, and it was very welcome as co-op is guaranteed to improve any game. The comedy of the game was also great. I'm not saying it's particularly hilarious, it's just that it's an RTS that doesn't take itself seriously, which again, not a lot of RTS games do. It does have it's moments though that are genuinely funny, especially from the live-action performances of Tim Curry, George Takei, and JK Simmons. The story is also appropriately absurd and great if you don't want to take yourself seriously.Gameplay wise, there are much deeper RTS games to play besides this one. Again, don't dismiss it because of that, it's still fun, but if you are looking for a very strategic RTS, this isn't the one. Not to say the strategic element is completely lacking, the three factions all have their own play styles which can translate into having to alter your strategy depending on who you are playing as and who you are fighting. All three factions can also build on land, air, and water which also have their own strengths and weaknesses. Water is also prominently built into each map, so navies are actually quite useful, another thing that not a lot of other RTS games do. Like I said before though, the gameplay is good, just not great.Great game if you like RTS games and want a loony experience with one of your friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												I just recently purchased this game again on this steam account, I have the Complete collection on another PC, and have played this game for thousands of hours since it's release date, as well as other RTS series like Starcraft, AOE, Empire Earth however this is one of the Greatest RTS games I've ever played, though personally not as great as C&C: RA 2, which to me was the most enjoyable, but currently is not supported through Revora's online Multiplayer* system.The Campaign story is Cannon from RA:2 but is in a way that if you haven't played RA:2 it won't negitvely impact your experience, it is funny and gripping, especially if you get caught up into the moment when you play through, and you have the choice to play solo or co-op** The GameSpy servers are long gone, so if you want to do any online matchmaking with any of the features you will need to look up Revora's C&C Online.The game is well designed, with Land Air and Sea Combat, Good diversity between factions, unit promotions, unit microskills (activatable abilities), Support Abilities (Faction based abilities available to you).The existing Multipllayer community on Revora is small but active (and skilled)If you are not familar with playing RTS in online multiplayer, especially during the 07-11 era when the RTS E-sport scene was at its peak then do not get too upset if you go over to Revora your first few times around and you get crushed, they do have some great people over there.Great Soundtrack (Hellmarch is amazing), Good UI, Challenging AI, lots of maps, and a lot of Youtube content if your looking to see the game played before you make a purchase.If you are new to RTS games, or are a long time RTS fan who never played RA:3 I suggest you do, I also personally suggest you play RA:2 if your able to play LAN games or are satisfied playing against the AI.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2012
												Let me start by saying how much i loved Westwood Studios and their Command & Conquer  franchise. I was introduced to it on the Nintendo 64, with Tiberium Dawn(Or the original or those of you who don't know.) Red Alert 3 manages to nail the so cheesy it's good feel that the C&C series is renowned for. I love the live action cast, and there is great fun to be had in this game. The units are diverse as are the Factions, the Empire of the Rising Sun has units ranging from GIant Robots to Psychic School Girls, where the Soviets are more docile. Soviets are slow and powerful and the Allies are the most well balanced. Each vehicle has a special ability. This game feels like C&C and it is very fun, even if it isn't of Westwood stature. I highly recommend this game. My only irritation is the lack of buildings and new units. I'm looking forward to picking up Command & Conquer 3 and latter on Age of Empires III! So until then, this should hold me over! Try the demo if you're sceptical!

Posted: November 29, 2013
												The B-Movie acting in the campaigns that you expect from Red Alert makes the fun, dynamic, and interesting campaign levels even better. The acting is funny and the effort that they put into the story for the campaigns make it even better. All 3 factions are well done and balanced giving multiplayer a great feel. It is not "Which faction is the best?" it is "How can I play them to my style.?"The abilities that are included in your troops make it very interesting; such as the bullfrog transport and the various EMP abillities for Soviet tesla troopers. It makes the game more dynamic and fun, as you never know when your buddy is going to rain down a couple dozen squads of Soviet infantry into your poorly walled in base. In RA3 you never know what is going to happen next.I at first was playing on "Very Low" graphics for some reason, and I was still blown away at how much fun I was having; but then I changed it to "Ultra-High" and was even more blown away; the lighting effects, shimmering of water, lighting bolts, command abilities, lasers, and bullets, all combine in firefights to make it look absolutely spectacular.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												TL;DR Review:Red Alert 3 is a beautiful, terrifically fun game that also does some interesting things with the RTS genre.Long Review:The Red Alert series has some defining aspects - alternate histories, time travel, trained animal units, psychic powers - but its most obvious trait was the cheesiness of its cutscenes.  The Red Alert developers realized that trying to do "serious" FMV for these games usually ended up producing something nigh-unwatchable, like Command & Conquer 2.  So they decided to just turn the cheese knob until it broke off, and Red Alert 3 continues this tradition with pride.  It combines time travel and crazy inventions and Tim Curry to make a wonderful, fun mess of a storyline.  And the best part is that the actors are into it - they understand that the scenery here is meant to be eaten.But look past the cheese (and cheesecake) and you'll find a fun, very playable RTS.  The three sides all play differently, with the Russians being the simple bruisers, the Empire having the coolest (but most difficult to use) units and the Allies having the most useful commander powers.Plus, the game has co-op.  The "single player" campaign is actually designed to be played by two people at once, each controlling a different commander.  Since co-op multiplayer is the best multiplayer, it was nice to see this finally come to the RTS genre.  And don't worry - if you don't have anyone to play with, there are nine different AI commanders to help you out, each of whom has their own play style and personality.  As the story progresses and you move to the next campaign, AI commanders that used to be your allies could become your enemies and vice-versa - an excellent touch.The game is also beautiful, with some of the best water I've ever seen. Models are detailed, textures are rich and of good resolution and special effects are excellent.In short, Red Alert 3 may have disappointed fans who were eagerly awaiting the next "real" Command & Conquer, but if you take it for what it is it's a blast.Plus hot chicks.

												I played RA3 for about 4 years on and off, Its a solid and well polished RTS, by biggests cristisms are that the online servers got killed off when Gamespy went under and EA did nothing to replace them,Another minor issue, this game has a problem when running duel or mutiple monitors, your mouse cursor wonders off on to the inactive display, so you have to unplug your second or addtional monitors which is a pain in the rear.Common invalid complaints about this game are: a) 'its too 'cartoony' but that trend was really started by RA2.b) 'RA2 YR was better ' No it wasn't it was a laugh, but the balance in the RA2 YR was freaking awful,  it became a one faction joke of an RTS in multiplayer, Everyone just played as Allies, because Soviets were usless if you didnt rush in the first 5 mins, and playing as Yuri was just 'cheap' no strategy needed, just steal all the enermy units or boomer rush. In RA3 all 3 factions are very well balanced indeed. And you cannot spam your way to victory with only one unit type.c) 'too much micro managment' - Basically translates as 'the game is too hard for me.'RA3 was the last good C&C game to come out of EA LA, highly recomended if you can live without multiplayer out of the box.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												+ uses the updated version of the Sage engine, the one that debuted in Generals: the effects (especially the water effects) look stunning+ has a similar script that Red Alert 2 had: they toned down the seriousness of the very first game and instead included some funny dialogues to help with the cheesy storyline+ ambitious casting, perhaps the best in the entire series with Tim Curry, Peter Stormare, Jonathan Pryce and J.K. Simmons just to name a few+ inclusion of offshore battlegrounds: almost every building can be built on water; this gives way to newer tactics+ finally, a 3rd faction we can choose from: the Empire of the Rising Sun is an instant favourite thanks to the unit variation (plus George Takei!)- ore fields were removed: we now have stationery ore mines that are nice but cutting of the enemy's' resources now is not as important or effective as it used to be- campaign could have been a little longer: while there are 9 missions with each side completing the first 4-5 does not take very long- the game desperately tries to show something new with the inclusion of the naval warfare: this is not necessarily a problem but throughout the campaign there's too much emphasis on it - mediocre coop integration: while playing all 27 levels with a friend is pretty cool, playing solo is pretty difficult at times due to the dumbed-down A.I. that is not always helpfulTo summarise: for me the number 2 will be the essential Red Alert title but this one was also pretty neat back in 2008. Running it on modern PCs can be a tad bit difficult - thanks to the uploaded guide available you can find some fixes for the game.

Posted: May 12, 2014
												This game is going offline here pretty soon thanks to EA dropping support for the "less than 1%" of their playerbase across over 50 of their titles. Regardless, this is a RTS game that would still remain fantastic to play in singleplayer OR co-op with a friend, as everything does work with Hamachi and if you have a disc version, Gameranger works too. The game has an extensive list of tutorials that for the most part a seasoned C&C player can entirely ignore and figure the new stuff out themselves, but as far as features go, this game is the closest thing to a Westwood C&C styled game that has come out since their demise. No squad system, extreme countering-style units, extreme diversion amongst the factions (the fast-paced allies, the turtle-heavy soviets, and the...asians), diverse base construction (finally bringing walls back) and a ton of lighthearted and extremely amusing missions and dialogue from units and the campaign with rocking music featuring Tim Wynn, James Hannigan, and of course, Frank Klepacki from the westwood titles helping to soundtrack as well. That said, the campaign is absolutely fantastic by ANY standard - FMV cutscenes that add up to somewhere around an hour in length and use top notch actors such as J.K. Simmons and George Takei.As far as how well this game can bring in new players to the series, it's extensive campaign and the fact that 1 of the 3 campaigns (Soviet one) is almost explicitly designed to ease players into the gameplay makes this a FANTASTIC entry point for newcomers. The tutorial itself consists of 6 amusing tutorials that really don't feel tedious despite totalling about an hour in length to explain the game mechanics, and are entirely skippable for anyone who's familiar with certain aspects of C&C or basic RTS controls to either see newer features or try to figure it out themselves. And for those not particularly happy with the soviet campaign style of easing players in, the allies campaign as well as empire campaign are notably more difficult right off the starting line and clearly designed with veteran players in mind. The campaign endings are lackluster so don't expect anything amazing, but the story throughout each campaign is rather intriguing. And yes, I keep going back to the campaign - that is really where the most work went into this game, clearly. The campaign at all points in time gives you an AI partner of a certain personality, each personality having a different playstyle. If you don't want an AI partner, it's possible to have a friend play with you instead in co-op, replacing the AI partner. The AI isn't particularly bad, however, and you are capable of issuing 4 basic commands (Strike area, strike target, plan (build up and launch) attack, don't attack) to your AI companion in an attempt to order them around like you would with another player.As far as skirmish goes, it does provide a lot of replayability as once again, you can call in these AI personalities to fight with or against you. Likewise, in multiplayer which will be limited to LAN-based hosting services or just straight up REAL LAN if anyone still uses that, other players can join you and you can still add AI or remove them at will. The limit to 6 players at maximum, however, is upsetting, and the map editor for this game does not work with the steam version as far as I can tell, but there's already plenty of community maps worth downloading and playing.For a $20 asking price, you are more than getting your money's worth. Compared with the considerably less westwood-like C&C 3 Tiberium Wars game asking $30, you are far better off getting this game and will undoubtably have more fun with it alone or with friends and it is by far the best entry into the C&C series as a whole for new players.

												The C&C Red Alert series is a francise that doesn't take itself too seriously.  Wacky unit types and off-kilter performances by cutscene actors help bring a bit of humour to the brutal business of war.It hasn't quite got the wide range of tactical options achieved in Command & Conquer: Generals, and the single player campaigns do feel a little short, but you are treated to 3 individual factions.Oh, and for the hormonal teens out there - there's a fair amount of cleavage in every cutscene.  Enjoy.

Posted: January 27, 2012
												Eigentlich kein schlechtes Spiel aber was den Singleplayer angeht ist es ein wenig langweilig. Die Kampagnen sind viel zu kurz und leider auch viel zu einfach. Dafür sind die Änderungen sowohl bei den Alliirten als auch bei den Sowjets super und mit den Japanern wurde eine komplett neue und ziemlich vielseitige Fraktion in das Spiel integriert. Der einzige wirklich ernste Kritikpunkt ist das schlechte Balancing, so ist die Heldin der Japaner beispielsweise viel zu stark. Die Filme sind dafür wieder ganz große Klasse auch wenn das meiste sehr vorhersehbar ist. Eine (eigentlich) gute Fortsetzung, welche aber im Singleplayer ruhig etwas mehr bieten könnte (Länge und Schwierigkeit) und welche für den Multyplayer eine bessere Balance nötig hätte. Fun macht es aber trotz allem.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												If you loved the Westwood Studios games, and played the legacy of Yuri through the culmination of Red Alert 1 and Red Alert 2.  You probably waited, chomping at thebit for this release.  After the debacle that was Command and Conquer 4 you may have even thought "You know,. C&C Red Alert 3 might be better, I loved Red Alert but I didn't really like C&C, so maybe this is the same kinda thing."  You would be WRONG...  This is the same thing, the same terribleness, not only that but it suffers from consolitous.  It really wants to be a console game, but it's not.  By using the Red Alert name, and hot chicks in the previews + cutscenes it atempts to trick us into thinking it's just as awesome as RA1 or RA2. So if you like being frustrated, and can't wait to waste money on this atrocity, you won't be dissapointed.

Posted: September 20, 2015
8/10Recommended PurchaseIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!ProsVarietyIn RA:3 there's 3 playable factions,the Allies,The Empire of the Rising Sun,and the Soviets. Each faction has it's own powerful commander-like unit. The allies have Tanya,a demolitions specialist that can one shot most ground infantry and can sneak inside vehicles or buildings to one shot them from the inside with C4.Tanya can also use her special belt to warp back in time to regain lost health.The Reds have Natasha,the greatest sniper in the Soviet Army,and she uses her sniper rifle to line enemies up and shoot through them all at the same time.She can also paint vehicles or buildings with a laser and have a bomber come by and one-shot them. The Empire of the Rising Sun has Yuriko Omega,a badass psychic in a schoolgirl outfit who can use her powers to instantly take a unit out of the fight permanently.She can also use her AoE attack and instantly kill units around her. Every faction has their own unique units and almost all of them are super fun to play around with. The allies have these helicopters that can each freeze one enemy unit and keep them there indefinitly stuck in cryostasis until the helicopter is destroyed.Each faction feels unique and varied and this makes the game incredibly more interesting and fun to play.FMV


Command and Conquer: Red Alert 3 
A Screenshot of Command and Conquer: Red Alert 3
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




In case you didn't know,before games used incredible CGI cutscences they used FMV (Full Motion Video). These were played with real actors and personally I think they look way better than the cutscenes of today but that's besides the point. The FMV scenes in RA:3 are superbly done and add so much to the atmosphere of the game,making it feel significantly more real. These scenes actually make you understand the characters and the situations better and that helps out the gameplay and the story both.General PowersEach faction has a singleplayer-only set of general powers. These powers can sometimeseffect battles greatly. These powers include things like setting up small bombs as the allies,to calling in drone kamikaze squads as the japanese, or even making it rain satellite debris as the reds. These powers can seriously give you an advantage by ambushing units when they're least expecting it or unveiling a secret group of cloaked units.ConsStoryThe story in this game is weird as can be. It involves Russia losing a war with the allies and then going back in time,killing Albert Einstein, and then coming back to a world where the allies are in a stalemate and a new faction of Japanese fanatics has emerged. Seems interesting but it's executed very poorly as the game could have made this work and turned it into something great but instead decided that they would make the game less serious and more funny and silly. The dialogue is so predictable sometimes and at other times the accents of some of the characters begin to fall apart and as you would expect,the game suffers greatly from it.MissionsMost of the missions in this game are actually pretty alright but there are a few,about halfway through each campaign where the game shoots up in difficulty. For example,one of the american missions puts you against the army of a rogue president whos incredibly well dug in and you're timed to break right into the middle of it to try and race him to a launch facility.Missions like this are never a good idea to put into and RTS game and much less to have both terrible missions and an insane difficulty spike.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

												Even though the multiplayer was officially shut down earlier this year, its still a fantastic LAN party game to play with mates, probably one of the best RTS's ever made, lots of variation in the units/races with lots of fun to be had in multiplayer skirmishes.Highly reccomend the RA3 Upheavel mod, which adds the red alert 3 uprising units into the multiplayer of the game for even more fun.(The multiplayer can still also be played over a VPN such as Tunngle, Hamachi or Gameranger)

												Despite the seemingly lack of hours, I've completed the game around 2 times plus on different difficulties. Just happened that I repurchased this game off steam recently. I would say that this game is rather well developed in terms of PvP but still lacking in terms of storymode. Ai is still pretty much predictable and the trademark win by numbers is still prevalent in storymode. It is considerably more interesting for PvP. However, I would argue that PvP still lacked depth compared to other rts such as Starcraft 2. Still good for the price. A worthy investment if you have spare cash to throw in hope of finding a decent game.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Command And Conquer: Red Alert 3 AKA C&C RA3 is a game based on stratagy. You must build your base, then build up a force to attack the opposition. It is single player and Multiplayer, so you can play with friends and by your self! Sure, this game is only for windows from steam, but if you have a windows computer, this is worth it to buy. There is also a campaign which I recommend you play as you can play as the Soviets(Russia), The Allies(America) or the Rising sun(Japan). This game is a complete update from the red alert series. I Guarentee you will like this game if you like war stratagy games.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I will start with the dislikes and move on to the likes (not in any particular order): 1. No multiplayer2. Units have very low health and you cannot do much before they are destroyed3. Co-commander is mostly useless in single player campaign4. Skirmish is a slugfest5. SHARED ECONOMY IN SINGLEPLAYER. Your co-commander builds useless♥♥♥♥♥♥and sends them into sucidal charges. 6. Lack of maps and skirmish customizability7. Graphics looks like a cartoon8. You cannot zoom out very much9. Campaigns are easy to finish and a short10. The Japanese campaign is a ♥♥♥♥ING CHORE11. Cheesy acting12. Support powers are overpowered13. No restriction of superweapons in skirmishGood:1. Hotkeys are easy to use and are very useful2. ALL units are well though out and balanced3. Good variety of gameplay and mechanics in each of the factions4. Graphics for this old of a game5. Special abilites are well though out and take skill and timing to properly exploit, not to mention thier usefulness 6. Easy to play, but hard to master7. Pretty balanced between all the factions and their units, minus support powers8. Good variety in singleplayer campaign missions (different objectives, playstyles etc.)9. Many approaches to completing an objective or mission. 10. Combining units, powers, and their special abilites are VERY cool to use and are effectiveOverall, I did not like this game as much as the second one, but it is still one of my favourite games.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Command & Conquer: Red Alert 3 is the 15th game in C&C series. Published in 2008, by EA.The story stared when Lieutant Cherdenko, General Krukov and Dr. Zelinsky from the Soviet travel through the time to the past to become alliance with Albert Einstein to make the Allies weakened and automatically make the Soviets is the winner in this war. But instead accidentally removed Einstein from the time and from this world. And they come back in the present. From what they have done is leading to have the third faction, the Empire of the Rising Sun, is going to dominate this world. The battle begins between the three great powers. This war called "The war of the three powers".Pros:-Three factions have their own specific style.-Very balance between three factions.(The things like C&C3 will never happen like hordes of Mammoth Tanks, Zone Troopers and Juggernauts are overwheilming you and you are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥e-d) -Different base building style.(Dem Japanese scatter their base around the map)-Co-op campaign that you can play with your friend. Only in this C&C.-Your beloved units from past games are here.(Kirov Reporting) -In skirmish you can choose commander for each facttions. Each commanders have their own playstyle(Bots only).Cons:-Short Campaign playtime compared to other games.-In campaign your bot sometimes useless.-No 4v4 skirmish-Unfair tech tree levelling. Soviets only have a single super reactor/tech lab, advanced units availble for whole base in the map. Alied required hightended/max clearance for each MCVs/outposts to unlock advanced units(If your MCV is fully upgraded but if your outpost doesn't upgraded yet, production structures that outpost covered still not unlock advanced units). Empire is the worst, you need to upgrade EACH of the production structures to unlock advanced units.Conclusion: It's a great game. Worth the money. If you want everything balance, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Don't let the campy plot and roster of B-list celebrities fool you, this is the best entry into the post-ra2 CNC scene to date, it continues TibWars' attempts at reintroducing classic CnC mom n' pops formula of MCV's and harvesters, but also learns from generals' attempts at being fun or thinking out of the box. All of this sprinkled with Esports aspiratons, that are anything but unwelcome. If you're planning on buyign this, get CNC-online, for everything else there's  mastercard  gameranger, tunngle, hamachi, garena and the like. CNC online is the only one that wants a legal copy, so if you aim to pirate this babe (and why would you give money to EA), use any of the listed above.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Since EA took over westwood the quaility of the C&C series has been on a decline and this is another example of a game made bad. it feels like EA is milking the money cow, starting the game with a time travelling story copied from RA1 with a slight twist where there is a new enemy in the form of the japanese. This combined with over the top cheesy dialogue and bad acting makes almost every moment of RA3 cringeworthy. while cheesy and bad acting is staple of the C&C series its used sparingly, the developers decided to take it a notch up and put it everywhere. pair this with bad taste (the japanese defending pearl harbour from the allies) one just cant help but question the idea behind the game.Gameplay mechanics have been changed a bit, now instead of having harvesters going for ore, we have deposits where we can build refineries right beside it. our harvesters need only move a very short distance, which totally eliminates the old strategy of economic harassing. the game economics has moved towards something like dawn of war where its critinal to capture "strategic points" to ensure a large economy. the factions are now full of "over the top units", allies have helis that shrink vehicles, soviets have cannons that shoot "cannonball men" (paratroopers) and the japs are full of stuff copied from animes (mechas and teenage girls). to some it might feel cartoonish but it can be a matter of tastes.the biggest drawback to the game play i guess it the "forced" co-op and the wildly spiking difficulty levels of the single player campaign. you must play with a computer beside you, which sometimes the ally computer player totally decimates everything on the map leaving you to attack the enemy base with 5 tanks and win. other times it cant hold its own leaving you to baby it, which spoils the game.the spiking difficulty is also another that spoils the whole experience, while i do understand that games use cheats to provide some degree of difficulty to the player. i found this to be used too often, even in medium the AI has almost unlimited resources and almost instant production capabilities. pair this with the uneven difficulty across the campaign, you'd quickly have certain missions where its near impossible to pass and those that are almost not impossibel to lose, right after each other.all in all, i felt that RA3 was cheap idea of generating some revenue. it has nothing about "gaming" to it and more on selling the brand which is RA. some might like the over the top stuff or the new revamped economics system, but i dont i heard that multiplayer is good but i have not tried it yet. for now considering what i have been through i give it a 4/10

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Game is great. I recommend it to everyone.Gameplay: Gameplay is great, three different nation with different playstiles and superiorities in air, land and sea. Three unique commando's in each side. Graphics are very good and in a perfect sync with the general ambiance of the game. Also the voice acting of the units is well suited and feels like every unit in the game has its own personality.As for the scenario, I don't want to give spoilers but let me say this: scenario is that when the Soviets started to lose the war against the Allies(US), they use time-machine and go kill Einstein so the nuclear weapons are not made. This eventually leads that Japan doesn't get hit by it too. So the Empire of Rising Sun(JAPAN) is our 3rd nation. 3 different campaign mode for 3 nations. Campaigns are well made, forces you to use different units and tactics everytime and there are bunch of unique things happen in scenario mode which are not present in the skirmish. Also the live-action videos in scenario mode with this cast is awesome (just Gemma Atkinson alone is more than enough). The different play-style of different AI generals makes game more stable to play solo too.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												This game is very attractive and smooth.....the textures of the human units are pretty pathetic but apart from them the game looks and feels fantastic....especially the water....and the environments.... A really good Command and Conquer game, which is just an all round fun RTS with cool looking vehicles and weaponry.... and it's got NAVY...HELL YEAH...great addition.... It's also interesting to see how World War II would have changed with Russia being the oppressing force using Nikola Tesla's inventions with Tim Curry from Scary Movie II as the Russian Military Leader and it was great to see George Takei from Star Trek as the Empire of the Rising Sun leader....  Without Albert Einstein assisting the Western Forces, Russia became the supreme power of the world.... I give this game a 7.5/10 It loses points because the human units look really crappy and they run like they got something in their tail pipe and also the animal units really irritate me.... Dolphins and Bears???? Really??? Apart from that...it's awesome!!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												J. Jonah Jameson was trying to blow up Moscow with a giant laser built into Theodore Roosevelt's head on Mount Rushmore, which wasn't good at all, because that would destroy my peace treaty with Doctor Frank N. Furter, whom I desperately needed on my side to help me defeat Lieutenant Sulu.Red Alert 3 is an RTS game, set in an alternate timeline after the Soviets went back in time and rewrote history (again) by murdering Albert Einstein. It’s even more ridiculous than it sounds, and serves as a worthy sequel to my all-time favourite RTS, Red Alert 2. It’s fun, campy, and often hilarious, while still serving up slice after slice of the Command & Conquer we all know and love.There are three campaigns to be played through: Soviet Union, Allies, and The Empire of the Rising Sun. Each campaign consists of 9 missions, and it took me about 23 hours to beat them all. When you’re done with that, there’s custom Skirmishes and the Uprising expansion to play through.Between missions you'll be treated to good old FMV sequences starring well-known actors, including a couple of surprise cameos. These serve to convey the story, relay your mission objectives, and make you snort Pepsi out of your nose, especially when Tim Curry or J. K. Simmons is speaking.The soundtrack is a blast, and Frank Klepacki, the musical genius behind the rocktronic compositions for the original C&C through to Renegade, returns once more for three tracks: Hell March 3, Grinder 2, and The Red Menace, which steal the show above the rest of the game's music. Pity he didn't compose the entire soundtrack.But RA3 suffers from two flaws: Co-op, and hand-holding. These two elements work together to steal away your freedom. Each mission is designed to be played with a partner, but since EA have shut their servers down, you’re stuck with AI co-commanders. And before each mission, you’re given a step-by-step battle plan, telling you to go here and do this and move there and capture that.Gone are the days of freedom to approach a mission in any way you see fit, which would allow for multiple replays and different experiences. Now you’re stuck with every step laid out for you, and an AI blundering alongside.I used to find immense enjoyment in taking my time to complete a mission, as I slowly crept up the map, expanding my base, capturing all the enemy’s buildings, and then crushing him at the end. That’s no longer possible. Missions are too structured and linear, and my co-commander is always running ahead, blindly sending in troops and mucking up my strategy. There were moments when my co-commander completed objectives without me while I was busy elsewhere. Why even bother playing when an AI is gonna do the work whether you want it to or not?Then there were other missions when my co-commander failed abysmally at his task, and I didn’t have time to swoop in and pick him up before failing the mission. These were the hardest of missions, and it felt nice to have to actually work to complete them, even if there were only a few.But at the end of the day, I had so much fun playing this game that I couldn’t help but forgive it for its shortcomings. Red Alert 3 is glorious and zany in all the right ways. What it lacks in strategy and challenge, it makes up for by simply being awesome, and it’s a fantastic throwback to past Command and Conquer games.Now if you'll excuse me, 'I am escaping to one place that hasn't been corrupted by capitalism—SPHACE!'TL;DR: Forced co-op can be a nuisance, and there’s too much hand-holding, but Red Alert 3 is great fun nonetheless.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Not even George Takai & Tim Curry could save this dud, and that's saying something.The cartoonish units, the gaudy art, the absurd physics, the boring story line that casually retcons the entire series thus far out of existence (and for what?), an entirely dumbed-down experience and a new record for gratuitous bimbos makes one thing perfectly clear:The developers of this game have zero respect for you, dear gamer.  They think you're a boob obsessed simpleton who embodies every negative nerd stereotype to be disproven over the last thirty years.  By the way, give us your money.A sad, depressing end to a once entertaining series.  Will only make you nostaligic for RA2 and Yuri's Revenge.  Go play them instead and try to pretend that this turd was never made.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2011
												One of the few RTS games that managed to pull of naval warfare correctly. Naval warfare is a rather big part of the game, but it doesn't feel tedious and it doesn't feel like you are missing anything on the more sea based maps. Additionally this game nails co-operative play better than any other RTS game I have played. The missions are very well structured for co-operative play. For example on one map your ally is expected to defend an island while you go out and attack the enemy, and on another your base is in the water while your allies base is on land, and you are expected to perform a naval assault while your ally does a land assault. The music in this game is also pretty great, but that is to be expected from a Red Alert title. The unit designs are neat, from armored bears to tranforming mecha. This is a game that doesn't take itself very seriously and probably turned out better for it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2011
												Red Alert 3 is a fantastic game but it doesn't hold a candle to its predecessor, Red Alert 2.The Co-op is extremely fun and the multiplayer is intense. The FMV cutscenes return featuring George Takei, Jonathan Pryce, Tim Curry and J.K. Simmons (You may know him as Cave Johnson)The campaign is fun, fluid and will keep you hooked till the very end, especially if you bring a friend along for the ride. Visuals are highly saturated and full of color, fitting the games unique style. Frank Klepacki returned to compose the music and it does not dissappoint.If you're looking for a great RTS experience look no further, Red Alert 3 is for you.  9/10-----------------------------------------------------------------OLD REVIEW7.5/10 - Its Command & Conquer yet higly un-optimized. Great Multiplayer. Story is shakey.But hey. Hot women :D

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												It's one of the best RTS I've ever played, better than Command&Conquer 3. CNC3 is a little bit more serious than RA3 and the environment setting is a bit more depressing, very much similar to fallout 3. On the other hand, RA3 is more relaxing while playing for the environment is way cozier than CNC3 and the background music is relaxing as well. However, it doesn't mean that RA3 is dull for players who intend for intensive actions, background music can change from time to time depends on the battlefield conditions. The tactics in RA3 is more than CNC3 in my opinion, for each unit can have a special ability. For example, spy has a special ability to bribe the enemies and make them fight on your side so you can either kill em or bribe em.

												My personal favourite C&C game of all time, as well as an exceptionally paced RTS game. Just a shame EA abandoned this game when GameSpy shutdown their servers, even though the multiplayer has been completely revived for free via a third-party launcher, as well as the brilliant community that still surrounds the Command & Conquer games to this day.Command & Conquer trully did go out with a bang.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												As a fan of Red Alert 2, I was pretty hyped for this game. When the reviews came out, it was clear it wasn't the same experience as before, so I held off purchase. But when it came to sale for the low, low price of €3, I couldn't resist picking it up. It can't be a bad deal for that price, right?Wrong. The inclusion of an Allied AI commander clearly supposed to carry the single player campaign in absence of a multiplayer buddy just doesn't work. It's frustrating to have a lot of your fun depend on a dead weight ally. Single player campaign play is frustrating, and only really worth it for the FMV cutscenes. The casting choices are great, including the awesome George Takei as the Japanese Emperor. But, on that subject, the faction of Japan just doesn't feel right in Red Alert, and tries to steal the spotlight from the established factions in a way that just doesn't work. Red Alert's campy plots and cutscenes thrived on its mock Cold War feeling.From a technical standpoint, it's a fine game. Units are diverse, mechanics are solid enough. Undoubtedly the strength of the game is in multiplayer, which I haven't tried. But it just doesn't feel like it's a proper Red Alert game. Plainly put, I wasn't having fun with this, and rarely have I been so disappointed in a purchase.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Not a bad game. Finally we have more than 2 factions. Each faction has its own strong and weak sides. Even different building system. Visual side of vehicles is not perfect. Too "cartoonish". Previous parts of the series had better vehicles.  I mean you saw those units? Bear? Dolphin? That is too much. Humor you say? Yes, it is good to have humor. Problem is - we have too much of it. Good cutscenes, but ending is very short. Unique special unit for each faction, unlike RA1 with Tanya for both factions. To be honest, i like some things in C&C3 more. Serious campaign for example. Smarter AI. Infantry that spawns as group, instead of one soldier. Why do you need one soldier? He`s not Superman. Unit upgrade system. I hope if next part will be released, it will be more serious and will take best things from C&C3 and Red Alert 2.
