number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I've played so much Red alert 2, but this?And just before I start I'd like to state that I've had a fair share of both wins and losses, and that I'm trying to be as nice as possible...ugh, I can't stand it, it's just not fun to play, and this isn't nostalgia or anything, this is my genuine feelings about the game. They tried to simplify the game by giving the player less units to use but this only complicates things by giving them special abilities which if you don't use effectively you will get wasted (and if you're like me you'll keep forgettting you have them) and to top it off you've also got other abilities you can use which yet again not using them will surely make you lose easy peasyThen you've also got to manage your own base, pile up a nice attack and defense force all while you make sure money is coming in and you aren't being bombarded by aircraft (which got a stupidly good power creep due to anti air becoming weaker than a flick on the nose) all this piled together is just not fun, or satisying when you do eventually win. I just felt like I had the worst micromanagement session ever. Sure the other C&C games have lots of micromanagement, but there it was fun because things felt balanced, you weren't under this constant stress of needing everything immediately but only being able to get one thing. It's just, I don't hate this game, but it's just not fun for me...Only really good part was some of the new units are pretty fun to play around with, and although the game is a massive stress-out for me, I never felt like the game was unfair (except when the AI blatantly cheats bringing over aircraft faster than I can even lay out anti air defense...)If you have RA1 or RA2, play them instead (HELL RA2 with 7 Brutal AI on a non-Free for all game is more fun...)

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Known issue: there is a good chance u will not be able to play on the online service, with a person who is on the same LAN as you. This means no campaign co-op.  U can still skirmish vs. AI on LAN, and I would think u could both play independent games online, just not together. :|Beyond that, this is a "good but definitely not great" C&C, and while it has its fun moments and arguably some of the best graphics in the series, the gameplay definitely hints at the totally-broken, excessively-micro-oriented,"hey-guys-let's-ruin-the-franchise" direction that EA eventually perfected with C&C 4.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Isn't as addictively fun as Red Alert 2 and Yuri's Revenge, but, you know what? It's still fun, and it's different enough from other CnC games (in a good way, unlike CnC 4) to stand out on it's own. Like, there's a pretty interesting balance between naval and ground combat that doesn't make either feel like an afterthought, and the campaigns, while campy with pointless fanservice and mindnumbing writing, offer diverse scenarios.Now, one thing I really hate, it has lots of unnecesseary micro. Not only is the game full of hard counters so you have to order around units so they wouldn't get owned by their counters while concentrating their fire onto weakest targets, pretty much every unit has it's own gimmick special, be it a special attack or alternative fire mode, so the amount of unnecesseary micro is unberable. Red Alert 2 kept it way more simple, and if unit had several firing modes you wouldn't need to switch between them, meanwhile here it's not even Starcraft or CoH levels of micro. Worst offender is the new third faction, Empire of the Rising Sun. They have probably the most of alternative modes due to sizeable chunk of their force being transformers like a machinegun mecha that switches into a fighter and such, and you can't switch back for some time like you get with, say, Starcraft 2 vikings, so it's rather annoying.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												I'll be honest: I bought the game because I loved C&C: Red Alert2. I saw that the reviews were not so good, still I thought that the game couldn't be so bad, being a new version of such a great entertainer.I was completely disappointed. The only good things are the videos, all the atmosphere of C&C: Red Alert2 was lost. It's just an average RTS... Well, I think that it actually is below the average now. The units are futuristic, but in this way they lose the grip with reality... I mean: it was fun having anti infantry yaks and anti vehicle migs, it was fun having to build the airfields and everything. It was fun having to give support to the battlecruisers in order to avoid having them sinked by the submarines or the migs. All those units looked realistic in some way, even the crazy tesla coil. these new buildings and units look like they have no link with the real world. It's like they tried to make the game cooler and cooler, but they overdid it and it has no cool anymore.I'll go back to play the Red Alert 2, it's way more entertaining

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												Gameplay:Red alert 3 oversees an interesing  transition from RA2, incorporating numerous alternations to the gameplay that allows the game to be more tense as the designs shift more to what you will see in a serios RTS-- most prominently, ore becomes a confined resource which cannot be harvested exponentially by cramming your build order with harvesters. Units can be categorized into anti-infantry and anti-armor. Main battle tanks may be terrifyingly effective against armor yet at the same time they require five to six shots to kill some of the most cheapest infanty, which indeed is hard to grasp at first. As such, attacks emphasize on the cooperation of different units spamming only one type of unit would not bring you anywere. Micromanaging becomes vital through the concept of 'crushing levels' where infantry are subject to be crushed by incoming tanks while tanks are subject to be flattened by even bigger vehicles. Several secondary abilities and attack formations of the different factions also heavily rely on micromanaging.The single player campaign is also incredibly entertaining. I loved the cutscenes shot in real person. The humorous plot is mildly funny and worth a laugh.Graphics:Absolutely brilliant special effects with breathtakingly beautiful water. Personally I prefer the rather vibrant hue in RA3 instead of  other CNC games or Starcraft. Antialiasing options lags the computer more than smoothing out the edges, however the game does not suffer from antialiasing issues much even without AA turned on.Annoying bugs:The pathfinding system is a total mess.Sometimes units would take a full round trip around the building it just came out of before heading anywhere else.Units getting stuck on the road for no reason.Highly expensive naval fleet would randomly be stuck on the shoreline, becoming virtually worthless.Units would line up and move single-filed, slowing each other down.Nanocores of the Empire unable to deploy and stop en-route for no reason on certain mapsEA:The experience for the game would be much smoother if it wasn't published by EA. RA3 had great multiplayer potential as with the introduction of the competitive aspects to the game. However, the servers in charge of hosting RA3 online closed down and there has only been a community supported server ever since, and the popularty of the RA3 community has been ever plummeting since. You won't find as much players nowadays as compared to when the gamespy servers were still online, and as a result matchmaking is almost impossible due to the tiny amount of players still playing the game.Overall, the Red Alert 3 is a great game that could be great fun to play no matter by yourself or with others. However I certainly don't think that it is worth this price due to EA's unresponsible attitude towards this game. Buy it if you have some spare money to have fun with, but it is not on the must-have list.

												Most definitely one of the best RTS I have ever played, though the multiplayer can feel very "slow paced" once you've played StarCraft II on "Faster". This game can be played at a fairly high level in ranked ladders and tournament seasons, but it will never reach the same professional level as the StarCraft series because it lacks certain aspects that  seperate the professionals from the dabblers (e.g. hotkeys, divisions, team rankings...).

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												I've been a fan for the Command and Conquer series ever since Generals, and this game lived up to it's name (Unlike 4, which completely abolished one of the main cores of the game; Base Building)From raging sea battles to earth-shattering land conquest, to air superiority; this game holds an incredible amount of replay value.The epic score will kick in when your base suddenly screams for help as your foes try to take you down, or when you build a sizeable army to take the fight straight into the heart of your enemy's fortress.Even if you haven't played any C&C games before, as long as you have a depriving thirst for an RTS game, then this is definietely for you.(There are a few mods for this game, and many downloadable maps, some even with custom scripts to amplify the gameplay and to suit your tastes of war)This is my own opinion; I might sound biased, but I just can't get enough of RTS.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												I'm a pretty big fan of the Command and Conquer franchise, so I was very much looking forward to finally playing this, albeit years after its release.Unfortunately, while playing this game, all I could think about was how much more fun the campaigns of previous installments were, particularly Red Alert 2.The first Red Alert featured faceless pixelated troops that you'd throw en masse against your enemies. The second one took a completely different approach, with individual units being rather personalized and potentially extremely powerful (even GIs were a menace at Elite veterancy) and allowing you to wreck enemy bases with just a handful of units in the right spots (I remember being able to dismantle most bases in campaign mode with only 3 Legionnaires). The third installment seems to fit somewhere in between, but loses something to both.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Do NOT, I repeat, DO NOT Buy this game!!!It is Bad where to start.........Well first the "single player campaign" is really just a Co-op game meant to set EA's precedent of "we're sure when you wanted to Play single player campaign you really want a multi-player game and you don't really care about the story".Oh and now you cant even multi play this game anymore, the one thing that people said made this game playable.Well here you go buy a BROKEN game people. Support a way to rip you off go ahead,Second you CANT start as the allies until you play through the USSR first.Another thing where they just go back and remove Albert Einstein and the Only True thing that changes is that the USSR is winning the war from RA1 and japan somehow now has robots? WTF... Then where is Stalin here and where is Kain? (Yes Kain is in RA1) where are the Leaders of the USSR, Because I know Albert Einstein, had NOTHING to do with Stalin getting power.Also now that Albert Einstein is no longer exsists to remove Hitler from the Timeline what happens here? They ignore all of these things and also where is Yuri? This story line makes NO sense here it just throws out the all these people and events even though they are Part of WHAT MAKES Red Alert What it was and IS.next the Units are too damn cartoon like and clunky, I mean the Allied tank is a damn destroyer that drives on land your joking...... STUPID, STUPID STUPID, What were the EA developers thinking when they made this game, or better yet what the heck were they smoking.Oh and in skirmish mode you cant play 1 vs 1 against AI or a human player you need to go 2 vs 2 minimum this means that if there are 2 humans playing you need a bot on each side.Now the ONLY good part of this game is the movies and even then they are not that even good (but they weren't super HQ cut scenes to begin with).This game for Classic C&C Players is an Insult, but for new people to this series may like it, and I guess that is what EA wanted, But by making it like this and disregarding the past (IE the story) of the previous games and changing the game play the way they did was disrespectful to the story and to the fan base of this franchise.Again just dont buy this game. this game is broken, if anyone says buy it they are trolling you, or want you to waste your hard earned money as they did by buying this garbage. For the price of this go get a GOOD GAME. like company of heros 1 or Command and conquer 3 there is one Without the Red Alert3 tag.

												This game sucks. I've played for 60 mintues. FOV is terrible. Seriously, wtf??? You can't zoom out at all to see anything useful. It's hard to see any of your units. Nothing is intuitive. Buy Red Alert 2, it's way better. WTF EA, how hard is it to improve over the previous games?????  Any money you spend on this game is a waste! You're zoomed in on the tiniest aspect of the game. It's practically impossible to find any of the units you actually want. Seriously, despite all the graphical limiitations for RA2, it's 100x better than this. WTF EA how do you ♥♥♥♥ up an RTS this bad???Anyone doubting me: Play this game for an hour. The entire time you will be frustrated by the controls and your view over the map! C'mon EA, this isn't hard. 2/10. Terrible. Terrible Terrible. Don't buy this!!!!!! Find Red Alert 2. Old graphcs but a way better RTS and much more fun to play. To reiterate: DON'T BUY RA3! SERIOUSLY, DON'T BUY THIS!

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												The desperate leadership of a doomed Soviet Union travels back in time to change history and restore the glory of Mother Russia. The time travel mission goes awry, creating an alternate timeline where technology has followed an entirely different evolution, a new superpower has been thrust on to the world stage, and World War III is raging. The Empire of the Rising Sun has risen in the East, making World War III a three-way struggle between the Soviets, the Allies, and the Empire with armies fielding wacky and wonderful weapons and technologies like Tesla coils, heavily armed War Blimps, teleportation, armored bears, intelligent dolphins, floating island fortresses, and transforming tanks.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												I begrudgingly give this game a hesitant one thumb up, and mostly due to nostalgia. While I’m glad that the feel, atmosphere, and gameplay of RA3 remains true to the series, the gameplay feels exceptionally old. I can only suggest this game for people that enjoy VERY frantic, micromanagement heavy RTS’s – where your attention is constantly and absolutely split between no less than four different points of interest. A combination of wrist-tiring unit micromanagement along with trial and error is the only way to make progress in the campaign. That is very frustrating and exhausting, causing me to uninstall the game after playing only half of the game. The developers should have focused on FUN rather than sheer volume of “crap going on at the same time”.

content:
Posted: February 4
												Please read this review till the end cause steam only have 2 button recommended and not recommended. First and foremost if you looking to get nostalgic on this game, DON'T. Apart from the soundtrack and few live action this is almost entirely new game since the construction of each fatcion is different(and also most unit have ability) different types of upgrade etc. Several hours in and I felt disspointed in the level of camera zoom provided as some unit are too small and when I try to zoom in to select a unit it just wasn't close enough, To add to my dissapoint ment is the left clicking order issue( seems to deselect the unit everytime I auto left clicking too fast) and guess what? This totally ruins my expactation in my 1st campaign and the main menu is just...... too bland, just look at Ra2 main menu back when westwood is in charge of it, this look like some fresh graduate design it on flash. Other than this I have nothing to complain as I have only few minutes in. Oh, no online server too( you should know that game usually retain their online content on official server for at most 3-4 years(unless they have big loyalist which this game lost) or someone jusy make a private server. Not reccommended for old nostalgic player. But nonetheless it's a good rts(not great). Totally recommended to get when it's on sale for 85%

Posted: January 27
												Possibly the most disappointing sequel I've ever played.  I was a massive fan of the original C&C, Red Alert and Red Alert 2.  When I saw that Red Alert 3 was availabkle, I was very cautious as I was not a fan of the Tibrium Wars engines and the AI.Sadly, this game is rather easy to complete with a very "dumb" AI; but the real let down is that it has somehow lost the magic of the first 2 Red Alert games.  I purchased this in a full C&C collection pack and sadly I won't even bother to play the expansion pack.

number of helpful: 0 of 9 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												Red Alert 2 and Generals were significantly better but this product shows us why we don't see any more C&C games.  If you wish to play this "RTS," I suggest you wait for a Steam sale.  Though addictive, this almost-arcade style game is an exercise in frustration and futility.  The gameplay is like Whack-a-mole with lots of micro-management of dozens of units.  The game starts off advising you to begin the Soviet campaign.  What you're not told is that the game is unbalanced in favor of the Allies.  You not only have to defend against the Allies but against a rogue general who weasels your resources from the get-go.  During the Von Esling Airbase level, you begin with over a $100,000 but the rogue general comes in and takes it all.  You’re left with a large base but no way to defendant it but you work frantically building defensive pieces at a ridiculously slow snail’s pace.  The game opens the water spigot with information overload and gladly tells you that you have "insufficient funding" from which to build.  This is the point I started to question whether the game was worth it.  If the player is willing to resort to short-cuts by defeating the general before ordered to do so, Update: I should have mentioned that the game should take the dedicated new player 5 or 6 hours to complete a campaign.  My major rant, the Von Esling Soviet round forces you into taking a short-cut in order to beat it, i.e., take out the general first thing.  That’s when it stopped being an RTS.  I tend to replay rounds attempting to lower completion times but like I said, this arcade game is addictive but after “Generals”, a huge let-down.  Again, I ask myself, is the price worth it?  Meh.  Prior to purchasing this game I'd strongly recommend (assuming it’s not on sale) perusing the Metacritic user-reviews.  IMHO those are the ones that count and have this game rated between 6.5 and 7.  “Crap-fest” is a poor choice of words (my bad) but be advised most of the Metacritic complaints pertain to inadequate balancing and AI.  There are lots of complaints about RA3 being more of an arcade game than an actual RTS.  To quote Coach from Left4Dead 2, “I gotta agree.”  If this game drops below $20, I'll gladly go thunbs up!  Happy Steaming…

												I would rate this game 1/5 starsI've always been a fan of the C&C series, but when it comes to the Red Alert subseries, the childishness and immaturity of it is just too much to bear. Even if you don't care about the campaign, you're still going to put up with goofy units and their stupid voices and cartoonic gameplay experience. Red Alert 3 might as well be a game for children, it is so silly. For the hard of hearing or those who disable the obnoxous sounds that come with, you'll find no comfort in the more-of-the-same style of gameplay. There is nothing innovative about this game that makes you go "wow, I'm really glad I bought this game instead of a competing game from a competing series"

The game was modified slightly with harvesters easy to protect and faster to get money but the game overall is still reminding old times that I miss so much. Posted: November 21, 2015
												One of the best RTS titles in the genere combining live action cut scenes , colorful animation, and intresting base managment this is a title worth every RTS fans time. Units for each of the three factions feel unique and mostly useful and the ability to build most of your base on water and the land makes for some intresting base building mechanichs. The story being mostly zanny and almost cartoonish in its sterotypes, does come across as fun. The real fun however is the action and combat itself with each side having access to multiple units each with unique parameters and abilites that allow for many combos and playstyles to take center stage. All in all C&CRA3 is a standout from the genre and shouldnt be missed.

If you've played Red Alert 2 and you loved it, you will be THOROUGHLY disappointed by the plot that makes absolute no sense and the incredibly dumbed down gameplay.  If you haven't played Red Alert 2, you still may be thoroughly disappointed by the plot that makes absolute no sense and the incredibly dumbed down gameplay.

Posted: March 7, 2011
												RA3 sets its sights firmly on bringing a smile to your face. The mood of the game is enjoyably goofy and nowhere is this more evident than the completely gratuitous sexy women who practically cavort for your pleasure.  The game mechanics are no less entertaining with loads of odd military units like attack dolphins, armored blimps, and football talking troopers.  Unfortunately the units aren't quite so devastatingly useful as RA2 offered, -it's a rare thing when a single, properly managed unit can land the blows to win a game, and more's the pity.  Furthermore the superpowers are a little more niggly to obtain and less brutally satisfying.The game plays out much more methodically than RA2 or C&C3 did so that you will have to spend more attention on individual unit tactics rather than massed forces.  This makes the game less friendly to "turtle" game tactics but grants a feeling of earned superiority when you finagle the most out of your limited resources.Lots of fun, in short.  :)

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Though I've logged only 4 hours on this game, I am quite familiar with Red Alert 2 and other RTS games. Simply, EA has destroyed what was once a great franchise. The units themselves are woefully balanced with some units being destroyed instantly. The difficulty of the game is quite frustrating considering that the game itself is poorly scripted, as there are multiple bugs. I've had problems with units failing to complete their movement due to poor pathing. Some units will just stop if their path is momentarily blocked. Siege units are insanely powerful while infantry and many other units are simply irrelevant. It seems that the Soviets in particular lack any sort of meaningful anti air units as the Bullfrogs and MiGs have light armor values and can be decimated by units of other regions. Flak troopers may be cheap but without any ability to traverse water, there is essentially no sufficient anti air. The Scorpion unit of RA2 was completely removed, which were some of the best anti air units that the Soviets had at their disposal.In addition, the campaign missions seem to be poorly designed. Just recently I played a mission in which the Soviet player had to assassinate the Emperor of the Rising Sun with a single Conscript. It seemed as illogical that there were areial units flying that failed to notice the enemy Conscript. As the mission continued, my base was assaulted by a wave of enemy tanks before any sort of player could mount a resistance force. The missions are boring and uninteresting. The acting and writing is subpar. The unit AI seems almost idiotic and inconsistent with some units agressively pursuing enemy units while other times standing their ground and just letting themselves be defeated.In sum, I was wholeheartedly dissapoointed at this game. EA has (unsurprisingly) ruined another franchise. Just play RE2, which I still do. It may be older but at least it was well made in comparision to RE3, a♥♥♥♥♥♥game.

												I reccomend Red alert 3, now i won't review the gameplay or anything else related to that since you can find reviews for thoose elsewhere, Many people who are nostalgic for Red alert 2 and the games before automaticaly hate this game since it changed alot from the original concept, and for the better since it added many new mechanics and overall i really love this game with it's superb campaign and multiplayer, Now many people know that gamespy shut down, well that means you can't play online right? wrong. there are over 300 people who play red alert 3 multiplayer via cnc online, you can google that and download it, it's really easy once you download that's it you just go into red alert 3, click on multiplayer and register. So try to ignore the reviews made by "Veterans" who are nostalgic of the old games and try to install this if you want to play multiplayer. if you're a newcomer into the series i highly reccomend C&C Red alert 3 to be the game you start with since it clears things up.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												The Command & Conquer series were a huge part of my childhood, mainly Red Alert 2 and Yuri's Revenge, and while this game definitely has lost alot of its classic elements from back in the day, the amount of improvements it has made is finaminal. Pros:-Three different campaigns you can do at your own pace and difficulty-Numerous units on sea, land and air (something that alot of RTS games don't have)-Online Multiplayer-After over 100 hours, I haven't found a single bug or glitch, besides occasional character movement around corners and water.-Skrimish mode, where you can practice your strategies on AI's -Babes, telling you what to do in the videos as you try to impress them throughout the game. Lmao.Cons:-Mediocre Graphics, not nearly as fancy as the videos.-Pretty dull story mode-The acting in the videos isn't too great, but what can you expect, right?-Costs alot when it comes to money (and time haha)... but it's worth it, in my true opinion.All in all, when comparing the factors I look for in a game, the pros heavily outweigh the cons the way I see it. Again, this is only my opinion, so if you can immerse yourself in another World War 2 story-mode game, then good for you man, I'm glad you enjoy it. 9/10 Better than minecraft on all fronts. Edit: Also, I adore the light humor sprinkled across this game, especially the Tutorial. The best part of the entire game is when the tanks get in the drive-thru line to get burgers....

												The story is worthful but the multiplayer is just another unbalanced C&C from EA games. This game is nothing like the epic RA2. oh and it is nearly dead anyway....where should i start from? red alert 3 is so casual and unbalanced it is only about who blobs more it does not matter what units u combine. there is a lot of micro options but no one uses them everyone just goes for blobing since it is easy win. there is a new army called Rising sun this army has nothing in common with the other 2 factions and it is super easy to play with it, your ground units can conver to air units and become either anti air or anti ground unit.bring a combined army of jets + tanks + infantry + ships + everything and your oppenent comes with only dogs and he wins you. this game is that stupid. it is only about who blobs more...who am i? i am 9 years veteran company of heroes 1 player who took part in almost all tournaments and made it 3 times to semi finals (what is company of heroes 1? a game that i dare to say it is the most skillful and microful and balanced RTS ever made to the date in 2006 and so far i have not seen a single game which can challenge coh1) and before that i used to play Red alert 2 a lot when i was younger. so this review is from an expert RTS player. and it is so funny to see how RTS super casual players defend red alert 3 and claim this game has "skill and balance" just like CoD players try to defend their children casual game versus other shooters.do NOT waste your time and money over this garbage this game is totally dumb probably the worst RTS game i ever player after company of heroes 2. if you want it that hard just buy it for single player because it really worths for the story and completely ignore its pvp mode.

Posted: September 6, 2015
												If you're looking for an experience like Red Alert 2 then you're not going to find it here. The framerate is locked to 30fps, there is no support for 1080p. The story line is good, however. Follows on with RA1 and RA2's cheesy theme. However because you're locked to 30fps, with no real way of unlocking it, and because you can hardly zoom out so you are constantly stuck very close to map, and not to mention the units being incredibly sluggish, I cannot recommend this game.

Posted: July 9, 2015
												So, Red Alert 3. This game has always been one of my favourite stratagy games, and it also introduced me to the stratagy game genre, but enough about me and more about the game. The best parts about this game are probably the micro-managing and the differences between each faction and how to win with each faction, and also the greenscreen cutsceens are so funny! However this game does have a few issues which do have to be mentioned one of them being you can not zoom out! You may think that this is a poor thing to complain about but when you want to micro-manage a whole army you need to be able to see them, another issue is the pathfinding of troops, this can be game breaking sometimes, it doesn't happen regularly but when it does it can be VERY frustrating as your troops can't get past something or the enemy AI can't seem to move when they get attacked, but again only a minor issue. Now the biggest issue is multiplayer, enjoy not having it when you buy the game because you can't play the base multiplayer as the servers are down (Damn you GameSpy!) But there is an easy solution which is Revora and all you need is in a video which i will link now

Posted: August 16, 2015
												Great game, I've been playing it on and off for over 4yrs. The only issue I found was that they patched the game multiple times and now its a nerf version of what it once was. Allies and Soviets NEED to have a plenthra of low level cheap units or you won't win (turrets are wicked expensive). EA made it so unless you have 4 or more ore refinaries you can't reasonably create a battalion of tanks. It makes the game so much longer and harder because the AI just makes tons of various troops automatically and spreads them across the maps in seconds (way faster than humanly possible). Its cheaper to build a nuclear weapon in the game than it is to have 25 helecopters. Definetly don't buy just download a Unpatched version online. On unpatched Ver 1.0 Hard, I beat the game in a month. This version i cant get through half of the campaigns on normal.

Posted: July 15, 2012
												Right off the top I'm going to say that the story and live action cutscenes are absolutely abysmal. I have no respect for any of the actors and as a result I'm lost in a story with no coherent reason to progress, or even exist. However, the game mechanics, the controls and the actual graphics all work very well together in perfect blend of RTS perfection. Fans of the franchise will be pleased to hear that it plays very much like Red Alert 2; skirmish mode is back, as well as online which are both incredibly addictive. Building a massive army and tipping the enemy over like a pawn is one of the most satisfying feelings in gaming. Apart from the live action garbage, and a few minor bugs I've encountered, this is a perfect gaming experience. 7 / 10

Posted: November 21, 2015
												One of the best RTS titles in the genere combining live action cut scenes , colorful animation, and intresting base managment this is a title worth every RTS fans time. Units for each of the three factions feel unique and mostly useful and the ability to build most of your base on water and the land makes for some intresting base building mechanichs. The story being mostly zanny and almost cartoonish in its sterotypes, does come across as fun. The real fun however is the action and combat itself with each side having access to multiple units each with unique parameters and abilites that allow for many combos and playstyles to take center stage. All in all C&CRA3 is a standout from the genre and shouldnt be missed.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												What a game!!! Might be old but it is solid good. You won't be overwhelmed with impossible tasks to manage. The factions are fun and they are all different. The quality of the graphics are good even for today's standards. The campaign is entertaining and long, so you get to play it from each of the faction's perspective (Russia, Allies and Japan). You can put 2 or 3 hour in this game and you won't end up exhausted. There is one caveat. This game is single player only, even though it has a menu option for multi-player, but it won't work. I guess the game is too old and EA had to free-up servers. If you ever get done with the campaign, there is a pretty good skirmish menu against the computer. In my opinion there is good re-play value in this game for the buck you are paying.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Not a terrible 3rd title in the Red Alert trilogy...   I was an OK fan of Red Alert 1. Then I became a HUGE fan of Red Alert 2. In fact I consider Red Alert 2 the RTS title that got me into RTS gaming.  I had high expectations with Red Alert 3 when it released. Was I impressed initially? Honestly, no. I was a little bit disappointed with the game and really didn't like the Empire faction. I thought it was pretty damn cheesy. I mean this is coming from a game that is loaded with cheese. But really, I preferred my mind whack job faction of Yuri from Red Alert 2. At least they had some Soviet in their style. The Empire faction gives up too much cornyness with their robot units that carry samurai swords and whatnot. I understand it's the theme, but let's be realistic here. You wouldn't be winning a war with swords in Red Alert.  For me, Red Alert 2 allowing you to choose from real world nations after picking either Allies or Soviets kept a more realistic approach to the madness and you could feel a lil more attachment to the story. Red Alert 3 is all over the place. BUT, not all is bad in the game.  I still do love the gameplay and minor enhancements they made. The graphics looking stunning even right now with the current gen games out. The Soviets and Allies are still great looking and have some really awesome units. Who doesn't love building a mass of Dreadnoughts to rain down dozens and dozens of missles? When the damage flies, it flies.  As I got this game on a cheap Steam sale, I figured why the hell not, and I'm happy for it. I stuck mostly with skirmish game matches where I could just have quick fun of building my base and laying waste to my opponent.   Where I didn't see much in this game initially upon launch, I found late in it's life thru Steam. At this point I recommend the game, but it will never be held to the standard I had with Red Alert 2.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												One of the few games I truly love. The game have a pretty funny story and not very serious at all. As an Age of Empire 2 lover I also want a change of pace and fight with something like tanks and laser cannon rather than bows and swords. And better yet, fight by commanding an army of robot! The unit types in this game counter each other to the point that a lowly infantry can withstand a blow from the main gun of a tsunami tank (but not its tread of course). The King Oni shoots laser beam from its eyes are vulnerable to infantry (yes, infantry) without its secondary ability. King Oni can finish off buildings and armored vehicles and blow them up to oblivion, but gaze that scary glowing eye of yours at a Conscript, for example, and congrat comgrades, experience how lame you can be.It pretty much like rock paper scissor. In short : the unit strengths and weaknesses are enhanced, and heavily amplified. Get the right units and you will raze their base to the ground, get the wrong ones, and totaloo, your base will be razed to the ground, oh and your pride as a RTS strategist, too, if you have any.The pace of battles is very fast for me, the outcome of combat is decided pretty quickly, and you better put your godlike microskillz to use, else, screw micro managing, just right click your way to victory.The differences of three forces: Allies, USSR, and Japan Empire are very diversified. The Allies has Air superiority, the Japan Empire, of course, master of the sea. Finally the USSR prefers to fight on land (yes, LAND WARFARE) basically if you confront them head on, and they are not hindered by your navy or air force, then you are dead my friend; the Red army will mow you down, they loves using brute force.There are lots of tatics and tricks that can be used, thanks to the special ability of some units.Joking aside, to be honest, I bumped onto this game when it was on sale and it was the best bargain I can get with just $5.

												What a game!!! Might be old but it is solid good. You won't be overwhelmed with impossible tasks to manage. The factions are fun and they are all different. The quality of the graphics are good even for today's standards. The campaign is entertaining and long, so you get to play it from each of the faction's perspective (Russia, Allies and Japan). You can put 2 or 3 hour in this game and you won't end up exhausted. There is one caveat. This game is single player only, even though it has a menu option for multi-player, but it won't work. I guess the game is too old and EA had to free-up servers. If you ever get done with the campaign, there is a pretty good skirmish menu against the computer. In my opinion there is good re-play value in this game for the buck you are paying.

												The game I'm sure was once great, and the new integration of multiplayer co-op through the campaign added a new and fun way to make your way through the scenarios. However EA had previously hosted the online servers through Gamespy, which has since December 2013 been shut down. EA has not produced an alternate hosting solution for Red Alert 3, and it does not seem like they will as this is not a Madden game or a Battlefield game. Therefore you are stuck playing the single player campaign missions with an AI co-op partner, which sucks eggs. So like other reviewers have stated, the single player alone is not enough to carry this game, and one must engage in the multiplayer aspect to truly appreciate the new mechanics. But since EA isn't hosting the multiplayer anymore the game is no longer worth playing.http://answers.ea.com/t5/Command-Conquer-The-Ultimate/Command-amp-Conquer-Red-Alert-3-Experiencing-Login-Issues/td-p/1557593

												Right off the top I'm going to say that the story and live action cutscenes are absolutely abysmal. I have no respect for any of the actors and as a result I'm lost in a story with no coherent reason to progress, or even exist. However, the game mechanics, the controls and the actual graphics all work very well together in perfect blend of RTS perfection. Fans of the franchise will be pleased to hear that it plays very much like Red Alert 2; skirmish mode is back, as well as online which are both incredibly addictive. Building a massive army and tipping the enemy over like a pawn is one of the most satisfying feelings in gaming. Apart from the live action garbage, and a few minor bugs I've encountered, this is a perfect gaming experience. 7 / 10

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Not a terrible 3rd title in the Red Alert trilogy...   I was an OK fan of Red Alert 1. Then I became a HUGE fan of Red Alert 2. In fact I consider Red Alert 2 the RTS title that got me into RTS gaming.  I had high expectations with Red Alert 3 when it released. Was I impressed initially? Honestly, no. I was a little bit disappointed with the game and really didn't like the Empire faction. I thought it was pretty damn cheesy. I mean this is coming from a game that is loaded with cheese. But really, I preferred my mind whack job faction of Yuri from Red Alert 2. At least they had some Soviet in their style. The Empire faction gives up too much cornyness with their robot units that carry samurai swords and whatnot. I understand it's the theme, but let's be realistic here. You wouldn't be winning a war with swords in Red Alert.  For me, Red Alert 2 allowing you to choose from real world nations after picking either Allies or Soviets kept a more realistic approach to the madness and you could feel a lil more attachment to the story. Red Alert 3 is all over the place. BUT, not all is bad in the game.  I still do love the gameplay and minor enhancements they made. The graphics looking stunning even right now with the current gen games out. The Soviets and Allies are still great looking and have some really awesome units. Who doesn't love building a mass of Dreadnoughts to rain down dozens and dozens of missles? When the damage flies, it flies.  As I got this game on a cheap Steam sale, I figured why the hell not, and I'm happy for it. I stuck mostly with skirmish game matches where I could just have quick fun of building my base and laying waste to my opponent.   Where I didn't see much in this game initially upon launch, I found late in it's life thru Steam. At this point I recommend the game, but it will never be held to the standard I had with Red Alert 2.

												One of the few and best RTS games on Steam that I enjoyed and recommend.Red Alert 3 comes with solid gameplay,fun and well made storyline and decent graphics even after 6 years.I used to play Red Alert 2 back in the day and I feel like RA3 is a worthy succesor.I really enjoyed atomic weapons in RA2 but due to the storyline those are unavailable in RA3.Kinda disappointed but the game still offers a wide range of global weapons.The battles are flashy and also easy to look at.The units feel responsive and easy to maneuver around even if you have a large number of them.The game offers tons of single player content with storylines that will for sure keep you playing the game.I absolutely like the fact that Command and Conquer games have actual actors playing in the cinematics and in-game instructions.Another reason I really enjoy this game's single player mode.In conclusion RA3 is a must have RTS on steam even after 6 years after release.

												I had on windows 8 the problem to change my resolution. everytime if I tried it the game crashed. But you can change the resolution still. U don't need to run the game for this way. Enter the folder "roaming" You will find it when you open your pc (C;ProgramFiles(x86)/users/yourusername/roamingthere you will find the red alert 3 folder if you enter it you see the folder profiles. there you can enter and change the resolution from 800x600 to whatever you want without tipe in any other stuff.the easier way to find this folder is to press windows key and r key on the same time, then tpe in the opened field just "roaming" and you will enter this folder. Posted: November 11, 2014
												I had a lot of fun games played in this so am giving it the reccomend despite a few real key drawbacks. Love building bunkers and hunkering down with a force to mow everyone as they came into the kill zones i built. The three empires build their buildings very differently. Japan is great at the start but it needs to double build everything by building an easily destoyable vehicle that rolls out and then goes to insta build that building somewhere. If you are on them as this is happening they are done. The main drawback to this game for me though is the superweapons. So super that all you really need is to build them first and you win. Dont need to uncover the fog of war since the maps are such that you know right were they built everything and just hit that spot without scouting it first. Then you roll in with a handful of choppers or tanks to mop up. If not for the superweapons i probably would have kept playing the game with a buddy a lot longer and enjoyed the challenge a lot more.

Posted: November 3, 2011
												The Red Alert branch of the Command and Conquer games has always been close to my heart. It was the very first Red Alert that got me hooked up on computer games. Since my childhood days, the series has changed a lot and adapted new ways presenting itself. Red Alert 3 has adapted a cartoonish look, but still holding onto the important things that made the series so good. It's not perfect, but it's fun and you can share that fun with a friend. The new co-op installment is an amazing idea brought alive. Every campaign may now be played with a friend of your choosing. Red Alert 3 as a game might not revolutionize the RTS genre, but it is worth your attention especially when not coupled with a full price tag of a new game.In conclusion, it's not perfect but it is enjoyable, and that ultimately is what games are about. Definitely looking forward to Red Alert 4.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												One of the few and best RTS games on Steam that I enjoyed and recommend.Red Alert 3 comes with solid gameplay,fun and well made storyline and decent graphics even after 6 years.I used to play Red Alert 2 back in the day and I feel like RA3 is a worthy succesor.I really enjoyed atomic weapons in RA2 but due to the storyline those are unavailable in RA3.Kinda disappointed but the game still offers a wide range of global weapons.The battles are flashy and also easy to look at.The units feel responsive and easy to maneuver around even if you have a large number of them.The game offers tons of single player content with storylines that will for sure keep you playing the game.I absolutely like the fact that Command and Conquer games have actual actors playing in the cinematics and in-game instructions.Another reason I really enjoy this game's single player mode.In conclusion RA3 is a must have RTS on steam even after 6 years after release.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												Is this the best C&C game? No. Is this game as memorable Red Alert 2? No. Yet when this game goes on sale for $5, then it becomes very much a worthwhile purchase. To clearify - the game's story isn't bad, I personally find it to be fairly solid (although nowhere near as good as RA2) the campaign is has a decent length. The gameplay although fairly familair to veterans of the C&C franchise is a bit slower than that of the previous titles. In this game resources are gathered from a resource node - in eariler titles the way of gathering resources was to build refineries around a resource field. This change both slows the game while simultaniously makes the need for early expansion greater. But what this system allowed for is the advanced naval system. The system allows for a base to be built on either land or water - an interesting and surprisingly functional mechanic. But before I conclude, the biggest issue with the game is (this may or may not be resolved after this review is posted) that the multiplayer is not functional. When the game first launched it featured a co-op mode for the campaign (can be played singleplayer without a problem) but due to gamespy shutting down, there is no way to play multiplayer with anyone (LAN may be the exception but I have never tested it) Ultimately for $5 on sale, this is not a bad game to grab otherwise - I'd recommend either waiting or getting RA2.

I never truly care about any other Command and Conquer game. Red alert was the only thing for me.  Gameplay and controlling was easy. Game storyline was very good and cutscenes was an awesome red alert classic. When we come to Red Alert 3 lots of people dissapointed. Because they think the game lost its old soul. But in my opinion they were wrong. All i see was improvement of old games without losing its soul. Better commanding. Better cutscenes.(With lots of beauties from mother russia, england and japan :)  ) Very nice new units and improvements to the old units from previous games. Balanced and fun increased nations to play with increased numbers. This game still rocks! Too bad that gamespy is down and we cannot play it multiplayer. :(

												I reccomend Red alert 3, now i won't review the gameplay or anything else related to that since you can find reviews for thoose elsewhere, Many people who are nostalgic for Red alert 2 and the games before automaticaly hate this game since it changed alot from the original concept, and for the better since it added many new mechanics and overall i really love this game with it's superb campaign and multiplayer, Now many people know that gamespy shut down, well that means you can't play online right? wrong. there are over 300 people who play red alert 3 multiplayer via cnc online, you can google that and download it, it's really easy once you download that's it you just go into red alert 3, click on multiplayer and register. So try to ignore the reviews made by "Veterans" who are nostalgic of the old games and try to install this if you want to play multiplayer. if you're a newcomer into the series i highly reccomend C&C Red alert 3 to be the game you start with since it clears things up.

Posted: April 3
												A good RTS in all regards, in my opinion, but lets go over it step by step.There are three factions available, all with their own unique play style, and sets of weaknesses and strengths. Compared to Red Alert 2, the differences are more stark, and it goes from units to base-building styles. In addition to that, every faction has 3 different AI's, with their own play-styles.If you're looking for a "serious" RTS, I'd suggest looking elsewhere, but RA3 is quite light hearted and cheesy(in an appealing kind of way), especially when it comes to acting and outfits in the campaign videos. Overall, it creates a feeling of a B grade movie from the mid 2000's, again, in a good way.As for issues, I would say that the balance is a little off, and the Empire gets slightly preferntial treatment, compared to the classic Soviets and Allies, but it's quite easily circumvented, as the effectiveness of your chosen faction is dictated by your own skill, and knowledge of each unit's strengths and weaknesses.If you're looking for a fun, light-hearted RTS that doesn't take itself all to seriously, flavor-wise, but at it's core, is a well made game with different levels of depth, go right ahead, buy it, you won't regret it.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												The third installment in the Red Alert universe is the best one yet. Combining all the classic elements of its predecessors that made those games great; Red Alert 3 is an RTS done right. Among all the usual fare like Campaign and Skirmishes, there are also lots of battles to be faught online and new experiences to be had in single player with the live action cutscenes. Let's face it guys, the acting is really corny. But who needs good acting when you've got jugs? Lots of jugs. In fact, if you are a fan of jugs you will want to buy this game whether or not you're actually into RTC. But seriously, there's a lot of content to be experienced in this, and its expansion which can be bought separately. I personally really enjoy the new Empire of the Rising Sun faction, as it adds a modular twist to the usual units we're used to seeing and thus changes up the game significantly. Graphics wise it runs very smooth and on nearly any system these days. The art style is one of a more lighter-hearted nature. But then again, that goes hand in hand with the direction of the game and the universe. Red Alert has always been the more cheeky, sci-fi cousin of the Tiberium and Generals universes and stands alone as a unique and interesting one at that. THe pacing of the game is fantastic, the audio is pretty decent (especially the music) and the gameplay is sublime. If you're a fan of any of the C&C games in the past, ESPECIALLY Red Alert, you owe it to yourself to check this game out.

												I can like this game and I want to love it.  There are so many good things that I feel I have to give it a thumbs up but.....If you plan to get this to play offline skirmish and want to do so from time to time with a friendly AI with you, just something to relax and play around with some very silly units...I havn't raged so hard at friendly AIs since C&C3.  I set both my friendly AI and the enemy AI to the same level but for reasons I can't understand the game will make it so the friendly one will act brain dead.  We're over midway into a skirmish, the enemy has just built their super weapon and it starting to make some tier 3 units.  My friendly has (if I'm lucky) just started to make some tier 2, has no defences and not much of anything else.  The rest of this game is more or less fine.  It looks like RA2 with better graphics and has a story as silly as the acting of the people telling it to you much the same as the one before it.

Posted: December 5, 2016
												I remember my first game of Red Alert. It was in RA2 and I was the South Koreans. I got completely crushed by the Soviets. Something about how diverse all the troops were made me want to keep going and unlock their true potential. I practiced RA2 and the Yuri's Revenge expansion pack until I became a master, able to take on 2 brutals at once.One day, EA published RA3. I was so excited when I saw what it had to offer. I got the disk version and started right away. I was overwhelmed by all the new changes, like amphibious buildings and secondary abilities. It felt like I was that complete noob again.A couple years later, I retook my master's status here and mained Empire of the Rising Sun. I then bought the Steam version recently during a sale so my Steam friends can see that I play games other than TF2. This game is so visually and auditorily amazing, and it is probably one of the most balanced RTS's I've ever played. I enjoyed the campaign thoroughly and find that all of the maps are very balanced. TL,DR: 10/10 would get rekt by army of century bombers again.

												It's fine, but really the C&C series stopped being worth it after the first few games. All of more recent ones are just graphically superior rehashes without the same gameplay. Overall, would recommend for fans of the series. For hardcore RTS fans, look elsewhere, this isn't for you.

Posted: March 1
C&C: Red Alert 3- Solid gameplay- Not one glitch recorded, personally, since playing.- Live action sutscenes can be cheesey, with hints of casual racism and sexism, but honestly one of the reasons C&C is a nostalgic and well remembered title.- Campaign tiers are immediately unlocked allowing access to all three nations from the get-go.- Although there is an unified arc to each scenario each ending is unique  meaning you dont have to complete campaigns in any order, However I would recommend starting at the Soviets if you are new to the game and its mechanics.In conclusion,A nostalgic blast from almost a decade ago that still lives up well to its modern counterparts. I bought the game on sale, that being said I would buy it for the Steam RRP. Will be eventually purchasing the DLC pack to see what else this Gem has to offer.
